Indeed, as late as last week I was involved with a joint committee that was confronted with some of these matters. I suggested that we follow the procedures the Senate committees had followed to date to deal with witnesses and that was accepted. Obviously, to continue to engage in this particular exercise is not the way in which to operate and in future all committees will have available to them the start we are making with these resolutions. I do not want to claim that this will be the end of the exercise. The Parliament has taken this matter in hand after 87 years of inaction. Let us hope that now that it has actually got moving on this matter it will not let it drop and will continue to look carefully at these matters and revise and update them and, hopefully, extend the types of protections that might be available to witnesses.
I draw honourable senators' attention in particular to paragraph (9) of resolution 1, which states:
A chairman of a committee shall take care to ensure that all questions put to witnesses are relevant to the committee's inquiry . . .

When one is on a committee, or when one is sitting in on a committee as we in the Senate are permitted to do, one is often struck by the irrelevant questions that seem to float around. There are many areas that, when witnesses come before us, one would like to inquire into. However, I think it is only reasonable for witnesses to be asked questions on matters which are relevant to the inquiry. In that way I think the witnesses will be in a better position to deal with the matter and they will feel that their contribution to the inquiry is more pointed and specified.

I think some witnesses must have been very mystified in the past. I remember sitting in on a committee last year where, for half an hour the witnesses were questioned on a topic which I considered did not have any relevance to the committee's inquiry. When I asked the member about this afterwards, he said that he was simply pursuing an interest that had nothing to do with the inquiry but he thought that since the witness was there he might as well pursue it. I do not think that is good enough. I hope that senators and members, in looking at these resolutions, will take them on board and will act in accordance with them. Paragraph (9) states that it is the chairman's duty to draw members' attention to the relevance of their questions.
I will make a few comments on some of the items contained in paragraph (12) which I think are specifically very important. Paragraph (12) states:

Where a witness gives evidence reflecting adversely on a person and the committee is not satisfied that that evidence is relevant to the committee's inquiry, the committee shall give consideration to expunging that evidence from the transcript of evidence . . .

I think that is also very important. There have been some discussions in the committees that I have been on as to what we can do with this evidence and whether or not it is permissible to take it out of the transcript of evidence. I think this is an interesting direction to a committee that it may engage in that activity and that that is a perfectly legitimate and reasonable way to deal with evidence which is not pertinent to the committee but which is the result of some witness deciding to bucket somebody else outside and using parliamentary privilege to do so. I had occasion to sit in on a committee some years ago at which precisely that happened. Finding a way to deal with that matter proved extremely embarrassing for all concerned.

I do not think it was ever considered that parliamentary privilege should be provided to non-elected members of this community to allow them to defame and libel other members of the community at large while giving evidence on some matter before a parliamentary committee. If a committee considers that evidence of that type is going to be given, I think that, in view of the direction given in other parts of the resolution, the committee should meet in private session so that the person who is about to engage in that particular activity at least does not have the opportunity of getting that evidence onto the public record, regardless of what the committee does with its own evidentiary material. I think that that provides a safeguard. It provides a safeguard for people outside who in the past have been attacked by non-elected members of the community using parliamentary privilege. That is an area that some people-certainly the media-have tended to neglect. Since in many cases it may very well have been the media that was making use of that particular loophole, I suppose that may be why it neglected it.

I turn now to a couple of other matters, particularly resolution No. 4 which deals with the criteria to be taken into account by the President in determining whether a motion arising from a matter of privilege shall be given precedence of other business. Paragraph (a) reads:
the principle that the Senate's power to adjudge and deal with contempts should be used only where it is necessary to provide reasonable protection for the Senate . . .

It rightly and properly goes on to say that we should not be dealing with trivial matters, and then it uses the somewhat pompous phrase `or unworthy of the attention of the Senate'. I think people probably know what we are getting at; I do not think we need express it in quite so pompous a fashion. The point there is that when a member of the Press decides to describe all members of parliament as drunkards, as has occurred in recent times-the other place got so affronted by the matter that it raised it as a matter of privilege-the Senate quite rightly decides to ignore the whole matter as being so trivial--

TALK.START.PARA: —Typical House of Representatives.
—Yes, typical House of Representatives.
—Was it true?

—If it were true, it should have been best left alone. Really it is a matter which is of no interest to us; we have far more important things to do with our time. I am very pleased to note that the Parliament intends to rise above getting itself involved in discussions in the Parliament about those types of attacks. I think that by disposing of that type of discussion we will be able to concentrate-Senator Durack made a point of this, and I do also-on those matters which do constitute contempt of the operations of the Parliament and which seek to obstruct the operations of the chamber. We will be able to concentrate on attempts to bribe or influence the activities of a member and those activities which really constitute contempts of the chamber and of the parliamentary process. By getting rid of the trivial, we will be able to highlight those other areas. Mercifully enough, at least in this Parliament, since Federation we have been almost free of that type of activity. Let us hope that that situation continues. Nevertheless, the Parliament must have the power and give expression to the power that ensures that it will not be intimidated in its operations; and members of parliament should not be intimidated in giving expression to what they believe to be correct.

SPEECH.PARA: As a member of Amnesty International, I attended a meeting of that organisation earlier this morning. When preparing some notes on this matter, I reflected on how interesting it is that in recent times other parliaments, even those that operate in the Commonwealth tradition, have had what really amounts to a massive contempt visited upon them with the gaoling of their members basically for expressing in the parliament and in their electorates views which quite rightly they should be permitted to express in a free, open and democratic country. So we should be thankful that this country has a strong tradition in this area; and we should work, as this particular set of resolutions does, towards protecting and enhancing the core of that operation. The reality is that it is necessary that genuine contempts of the Parliament be dealt with vigorously.

I hope that now we have the Act dealing with privilege and shortly, I hope, these resolutions passed by both Houses, we shall cease to deal with people by slapping them over the wrist with a feather. I hope that having cleared away the trivialities, we will treat any matters that come before us with due seriousness and, if necessary, operate with vigour. Ultimately that is the only way to protect the real privileges of the Parliament which, in turn, are to protect the interests of the people of this country.

In regard to resolution 5 relating to the protection of persons referred to in the Senate, I believe that it is important, as Senator Durack has said, to make note of the fact that we shall provide for the first time an avenue whereby people who have been attacked in this place can have a set course for redress. They may not always get it, it may not be judged to be appropriate, but for the first time we are setting down an avenue by which people can know of, and can go about seeking, some redress if they feel that they have been slandered, derided or injured, as the resolution says, with regard to:
. . . occupation, trade, office or financial credit, or that the person's privacy has been unreasonably invaded, by reason of that reference to the person; . . .

That is an interesting departure from previous traditions in this place. It shows that the Parliament itself is growing up in regard to how it will treat the rights of individual citizens and is acknowledging for the first time by resolution that those citizens who are affronted by having their names dragged around in debate in either chamber of this Parliament will have some means of redress. This is a good and proper avenue. I well remember the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) arguing strongly in the committee for this type of approach. He is to be commended for that, as are other members of the committee who have given a great deal of support to this matter. It is a start. One hopes that it will be recognised as such and that at a later stage, after there has been experience of the operation of these provisions, they can be fine tuned and possibly taken further. I am happy that at present we have progressed down this track. Let us hope that in the light of experience we may be able to give further protection to people who are attacked in this place without in any way-and in this is an important caveat-limiting or taking away from the rights of members of this place to speak freely on any matter they believe needs to be brought up in the interests of the people of Australia.

Resolution 6 relates to matters constituting contempt and I support Senator Durack's remarks. Interference with the Senate is a proper matter to be dealt with in terms of contempt. The resolution deals with influencing senators and where, for example, senators are seeking benefits. It also applies to the molestation of senators, which does not happen very often.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't know. Senator Richardson has a different view about that, I think.

—Yes, some Ministers recently have had strong views about that. Then the resolution deals with disturbance of the Senate, which happens from time to time. In the new chamber I am not sure whether people will have as much opportunity to create a disturbance. The resolution mentions the serving of writs in this place, and also false reports of proceedings. The Press may take note of that. It goes on to state:

SPEECH.PARA: A person shall not wilfully publish any false or misleading report of the proceedings of the Senate . . .

I am not quite sure how that ever will be carried out, but let us hope that the Press will pay attention to it. If the people representing Australian Associated Press who sit long-sufferingly in the gallery at any stage have falsely given misleading reports of the Senate, at least they have always responded rapidly to correct those reports. In fact, in the time that I have been here, which is certainly not anywhere near as long as the Deputy President has been here, I have never noticed in terms of at least those types of reports that there is any wilful publishing of false or misleading reports about the proceedings of the Senate. Such reports as have been made, I think, were made in all reasonableness because of an inability to follow what was going on in this place. That cannot be held to be a crime since on occasions I have noticed that most senators in this place have not been able to follow what is going on, either. On one of those particular occasions I remember that half of the Labor Party sat on one side of the chamber and the other half sat on the other because they did not know on which side they should be voting.

The other matter I wish to raise is the exercise of the freedom of speech. This particular resolution does nothing more than direct senators' attention to what they ought to consider when they are going to mention people or firms in such a way that detriment could be caused to that person or firm. Senators have to pay very close attention to resolution 9. I hope that they will. I believe that on almost every occasion they do so. There is a bit of a myth, I think, floating around somewhere in the community that people's names or the names of firms are bandied about in this place on a daily basis. That is not the case. Only rarely is it the case that particular individuals are attacked. When that occurs in the future the hope is that senators will have taken note of the five points contained in resolution 9 (1) and act according to their own consciences on these matters.

I indicate on behalf of my colleagues that the Australian Democrats will be supporting the amendments moved by Senator Durack. I think that they clarify these matters, and if these resolutions now go forward to the House of Representatives, where I hope they will be passed, we will have moved a step towards fulfilling our constitutional role to define clearly the privileges of this and the other chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate my opposition to re-solution 5, which relates to the protection of persons referred to in the Senate. I should indicate, first of all-and I do not know what the position is so far as the Australian Labor Party is concerned-that on this side of the chamber this matter is traditionally a free vote; there is not a caucused or party room view on these matters. We are all entirely at liberty to express our individual views and vote accordingly as individuals on matters which relate to Standing Orders and to questions of privilege. Indeed, honourable senators may recall that when the Privileges Bill was before the chamber, Senator Jessop and I alone voted against a clause of that Bill which related to the expulsion of members of Parliament. In exactly the same way I see an issue arising under this question of the protection of persons referred to in the Senate as a further winding back of the privileges of this Parliament and the creation of a situation in relation to persons who have been referred to in the Senate which I think is entirely unsatisfactory.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing that has to be said about resolution 5 is that it amounts to some sort of admission of failure on the part of the Parliament. It suggests, by implication, that the Parliament has not provided methods of redress for persons who think themselves to have been improperly dealt with or, indeed, that somehow there are large numbers of people in this position who are aggrieved and want something done. I am glad to see Senator Harradine sitting here in the chamber. I well recall that, when I first came to this Parliament, there was an ongoing debate between Senator Harradine and Senator Justin O'Byrne in which Senator O'Byrne made a series of accusations about persons in Tasmania-persons connected with the trade union movement, I recall. On a number of occasions the rights of those individuals were more than adequately protected by the fact that Senator Harradine got up and responded on their behalf.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—I can understand Senator Macklin's outrage that people should come in here and defend the rights of others. Defending the rights of human beings, as distinct from defending the rights of Antarctic seals, is always difficult for the Australian Democrats. The point at issue, however, is that Senator Macklin has attempted to say in the debate today that it is only by the passage of resolution 5 that we will be creating-his words were-an avenue for the first time whereby people could have the record set straight or could have a right of reply somehow brought before the Parliament. That is simply not correct. There has always been a method whereby people are able to approach any other member of this place or the other place and state their case. If they are able to persuade a member or senator that their case is one which is worthy of a response being made, that response always has been made. I do not know of anybody who has been put in a position where that avenue of redress was not available to him. The resolution is attempting to set up a very convoluted system. May I, with your indulgence, Mr Deputy President, just seek from the Minister an indication that he is, in fact, accepting Senator Durack's amendments to this matter and then I will address myself purely to Senator Durack's formula rather than the original.
—Yes, I am.

—I address myself purely to the scheme as it would exist under Senator Durack's proposal. The first point of contention will be, of course, that the Privileges Committee has the power to second-guess the President. Resolution 1, which is only affected in a minor way by Senator Durack's amendment, requires the President to be satisfied that the matter is not so obviously trivial or the submission so frivolous or vexatious or offensive in character as to make it inappropriate. So the President has to satisfy himself of that. One of the powers of the Privileges Committee is then to say that the President was wrong; under paragraph (2) in Senator Durack's formula the Committee may come to the decision that the subject of the submission is not sufficiently serious or the submission is frivolous, vexatious or offensive in character and shall, therefore, not proceed.

SPEECH.PARA: Rather than accept prima facie that the President has decided that it should be referred to, we have a situation where the President has to make that decision. The Committee can then say, `The President, of course, was wrong. The President said it ought to go forward because it was not frivolous, vexatious or offensive, but we have not determined that it is frivolous, vexatious or offensive'. I think in a procedural sense, if the President is satisfied, it should not be open to the Committee to lay aside the determination of the President in that particular matter. I think that is grounds of unnecessary conflict and of unnecessary potential embarrassment for the President if he believes the matters is of sufficient character that the Privileges Committee ought to look at it and the Privileges Committee then puts that to one side.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the Committee may get further evidence on which it makes that decision, surely?

—That is not the way I read it. Paragraph (2) says that the Committee may decide not to consider it. It is only if the Committee decides to consider it that under paragraph (3), if the Committee decides to consider, the Committee may confer. In other words, the Committee has to make the judgment to proceed in the matter before it goes through with the process of conferring with the person who made the submission or any senator who referred in the Senate to that person. I think that there is some ambiguity in exactly what is meant here by `confer'. I know that it replaces a far more rigid form of taking evidence and submissions which was in Senator Evans's original proposals but, again, I think it unclear. I think it to be a source of some considerable potential confusion.

SPEECH.PARA: We have in paragraph 7 (b) of Senator Durack's amendments another sticking point: whether, if there is to be a response, it will be published by the Senate or incorporated in Hansard. I am not altogether sure whether publication by the Senate or incorporation in Hansard then becomes a judgment of relative worth or value: should some things be published merely or should they be incorporated? If there is no difference, why is it put in that fashion? The next question therefore becomes: what is the status of that statement? Having been a statement of a person agreed to by that person and the Committee of Privileges, does it attract to itself, once it is published in Hansard, the privilege of the Parliament? I presume that it does. I presume that, having appeared in Hansard, it has attached to it some degree of privilege. So here is a statement made by a person who is not an elected member of the Parliament which has attracted to it the privilege of the Parliament.

Senator Macklin was very clear in saying that he had some problems which related to the testimony of witnesses before committees, with the extension to non-elected persons of the right of privilege which derived when a person was giving evidence or making a statement before a parliamentary committee. Yet, presumably, that privilege is now to be extended to a person whose statement has been approved by the Committee of Privileges for incorporation in Hansard. I say this will invite the Committee of Privileges to start doing something which I believe it has never previously done, and that is, it will invite it to start to divide along party lines when the issue concerned is of political moment.

Let us take a hypothetical situation in which Senator Walsh has, hypothetically, abused some member of the public and that person has made a submission to the President that he has been traduced and that he ought to have the right of reply, and the President has referred that matter to the Committee of Privileges. We then have a situation in which the Australian Labor Party members and the non-Labor members have a substantive question put before them which relates to a political judgment between a Minister and somebody who perhaps happens to be a member of the finance committee of the Western Australian division of the Liberal Party of Australia. Although the resolution makes it quite clear that the Committee shall not make a judgment about the truth or otherwise of the matter concerned-meaning, in effect, that provided the terms are agreed on it does not have to put a statement of truth on the part of the individual who is making a reply-that individual, under this resolution, is perfectly capable of submitting a statement which is a pack of lies and having it incorporated in Hansard under privilege. That is what is possible.

The person may make a statement which is not offensive or abusive but which is absolutely untrue in response to a statement made and that statement will be adjudged by the Committee of Privileges to fall within the tests that are put down in 8 (b) of Senator Durack's amendment. It may be fundamentally untrue and incorporated in Hansard with privilege attracted to it. Unlike the statement of the honourable senator, which is capable of being tested by resolution, by question, by motion, that statement by the person in reply is not capable of being tested by the way in which we operate in this chamber. It will be there.

A statement made by a Minister, by the President or by any senator can be challenged within this chamber. We can move motions. We can ask questions. We can debate the issue and we can see whether there is a response. So if I get up and make some statement about Dr Edelsten, as has been the case in the past, and people want to challenge this they are perfectly capable of challenging me to show the evidence, to defend the propositions that I put in the chamber. But the statement which is incorporated by an individual through this mechanism-which may, as I said, be absolutely untrue, and which attracts privilege to it by being published in Hansard-is not capable of being so tested, and I object to that. I object to the extension of privilege to non-elected persons in this way in exactly the same vein that Senator Macklin objected to the attraction of privilege to people who he believed were abusing their rights when they appeared as witnesses before parliamentary committees.

Resolution 9 deals with the exercise of freedom of speech. If we are serious about this-it will become a sort of code of parliamentary conduct for members of parliament making speeches-I believe that the protections of individual citizens are guaranteed under that. If we are not protecting the rights of individuals by the adoption of that code in relation to the exercise of freedom of speech, what is it doing in these resolutions? Otherwise it is just meaningless nonsense. Either that code regarding the exercise of freedom of speech we live and operate by and we test each other on the basis of the points that are laid out in it or it is mere verbiage, meaningless nonsense. If it is something more than that it provides adequate protection.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I put it to you, first, that there is an existing method of redress. That method is to have any member or senator-not a committee, not the President; the President or the Committee of Privileges does not have to test this-who is convinced of the justice of somebody's appeal for his name to be cleared if that person has been traduced to take the opportunity to make a speech in this place defending that person, putting that person's point of view and, if necessary, incorporating a statement or letter from that person with the leave of the Parliament or reading it into the record. So that avenue exists. I do not believe we have to create a whole new method of doing it. Secondly, I think this is a false remedy for a problem which really does not exist as a substantial problem. Despite what I might say about Senator Walsh from time to time and despite what Senator Walsh might say about individuals on this side of the chamber, I think by and large members of the Parliament have conducted themselves in relation to the rights of individuals in a pretty forthright manner and that the test is the test which we apply among colleagues as to the way in which we go about our business here.

No set of rules like this will prevent a person who is intent on abusing the system from doing so but this proposal sets up a mechanism which involves the President, the Committee of Privileges, potential conflict in judgment between both, a whole method of deciding what constitutes conferring with aggrieved persons and senators and a potential for political division on the Committee of Privileges, the strength of which has largely lain in the fact that it does not divide along partisan political lines. The issues that are likely to arise before it under this regime are more likely to be contentious partisan political issues. We have difficulties over the distinction between publishing by the Senate and incorporating in Hansard. We have difficulties in relation to the degree of privilege which is attracted by publication or by incorporation in Hansard.

We are setting up a system which is quite unnecessary. Adequate alternatives are currently available. Whilst I have no difficulty with all the other resolutions which are before us in relation to the rights of protection of witnesses before committees, the questions of legal aid, the questions of the code of conduct, and the questions of the raising of privilege and the like, I certainly very strongly oppose resolution 5 and I will certainly be voting against it, both in its original form and in the form of the amendments moved by Senator Durack.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Puplick said that his Party had a free vote on this matter. I assure him that that is the situation on this side of the chamber. Indeed, constitutionally we are all obliged to exercise a free vote on questions of privilege. Perhaps I can show that there is a free vote on this matter by agreeing with a lot of what Senator Puplick said about resolution 5. However, I will add a few other things. This procedure could add to the problems that face somebody who is allegedly blackguarded in this chamber. If I blackguarded someone and Senator Puplick said, `That is not correct', I could say, `We will see whether the person whom you say I have unjustly blackguarded protests. It is all right for you to protest on his behalf but he has a procedure that he can go through to vindicate his character'.

SPEECH.PARA: That puts the person concerned at a disadvantage because to vindicate his character he has to go through a procedure which I think, looking through this resolution, may take some months. There are letters to be written. The Committee of Privileges has to consider whether it ought to allow him to come before it. He then might have to go before the Committee. By the time all this procedure is gone through the effect of the original statement which he or she objects to has been lost. Surely, if we perform our duty as parliamentarians and representatives of the people, the best way out of this situation is for us to rise in our places, either that day or later, and protect that person's character by challenging the person who has made the statement to produce the evidence to back it up, or to vindicate in some way the character of the person blackguarded.

TALK.START.PARA: —What if no senator bothers to do that?
—That is a problem, of course. It would be an indication that we had failed to perform our duty.
—Why?

—Because if a person went to Senator Durack and complained, `Senator Cooney has insulted me. Are you going to do something about it?', and Senator Durack said, `No, I am not' he would have failed in his duty to represent that person--
—How often has that been done?

—It has not been done very often at all. But what evidence is there that this very clumsy procedure will be used when the much easier procedure of approaching somebody in opposition has not been used? It seems to me that what Senator Puplick is saying-I hope that I am correct in this-is that this resolution sets up a procedure, firstly, which may be used to blunt the effect of somebody wanting a rebuttal of a suggestion that has been made in relation to him or her and, secondly, that the procedure is very cumbersome. If one looks at it, so it is.

SPEECH.PARA: The person's vindication will not appear the next day or the next week, that is, within a time-span that will have the effect of rebutting what has been said against him or her. It will be done in a time-span that will have quite the opposite effect. In about two or three months, I suggest, at the earliest by the time this procedure has gone through a paragraph will be put in Hansard. What sort of vindication is that of somebody who has been grossly insulted? Although the procedure looks attractive, the actual application of it will lead to a very poor answer to a statement that has been made against the person who was offended.

I turn to resolution 3, the resolution which both sides have agreed to-both Senator Evans and Senator Durack. I do not want to suggest that this debate is going ahead on party lines. The resolution states:
The Senate declares that it will take into account the following criteria . . .
It then lists paragraphs (a), (b) and (c). I am interested in paragraph (c) (ii), which states:
(c) Whether a person who committed any act which may be held to be a contempt:
(ii) had any reasonable excuse for the commission of that act.
Contempt is defined, in effect, in paragraph (a) in the following way:

(a) the principle that the Senate's power to adjudge and deal with contempts should be used only where it is necessary to provide reasonable protection for the Senate and its committees and for Senators against improper acts tending substantially to obstruct them in the performance of their functions, and should not be used in respect of matters which appear to be of a trivial nature or unworthy of the attention of the Senate;

Nobody could reasonably argue that matters of a trivial nature or matters that are unworthy of the attention of the Senate ought to be raised to the level where they are considered in terms of whether contempt has been committed. I can follow that. I agree that any acts which tend substantially to obstruct senators or the Senate itself in the performance of their functions ought to be the contempt that is dealt with here. But paragraph (c) (ii) affords a person who has committed an improper act tending substantially to obstruct the Senate or senators in the performance of their duties the ability to raise in exculpation that there was a reasonable excuse for the commission of that act.

It is extraordinary that the Senate, an elected body, a chamber which passes laws for the betterment of the people of Australia, should be able to have its duty obstructed in a substantial way, and that that should be condoned if there was a `reasonable' excuse for it. Nevertheless, according to this commission clause a person who is not elected has the ability to obstruct the carrying out of duties by a person who is elected. Perhaps somebody can suggest to me how anybody could have a reasonable excuse for obstructing this chamber in the execution of its duties or senators in the execution of their duties. How could that ever be excused? That approach is quite extraordinary.

I turn to resolution 1, the procedures to be observed by Senate committees for the protection of witnesses. Paragraphs (9) and (10) talk about the care that should be taken with witnesses appearing before Senate committees. I agree that witnesses before Senate committees should be afforded protection. I think the resolution, on the whole, is admirable. However, paragraph (9) states:
A chairman of a committee shall take care to ensure that all questions put to witnesses are relevant to the committee's inquiry . . .
Paragraph (10) states:

Where a witness objects to answering any question put to the witness on any ground, including the ground that the question is not relevant or that the answer may incriminate the witness, the witness shall be invited to state the ground . . .
Paragraph (12) states:

Where a witness gives evidence reflecting adversely on a person and the committee is not satisfied that the evidence is relevant to the committee's inquiry, the committee shall give consideration to expunging that evidence from the transcript of evidence, and to forbidding the publication of that evidence.

The question of relevancy should perhaps be explained. If `relevant' is used in the sense that it is used in the law of evidence, that is, that it makes a particular issue more or less likely, then paragraph (9) is too restrictive. A committee should be able to test a witness as to his or her credit. If the question of credit is excluded from the committee's consideration by (9) and (10), that should be corrected. If the expression `relevant to the committee's inquiry' includes the ability to test a witness's credit, I have no objection to it. I would like it made clear to me whether (9) does mean relevant not only in the legal sense of making an issue in dispute more or less likely, but also in the sense of credit- -

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no way to qualify whether you say it does or not.

—No, but if the use of the word `relevant' in paragraph (9) is used in the legal sense, which is a question of whether a particular piece of evidence makes an issue in fact more or less likely, that particular paragraph excludes the ability of the Committee to put questions as to credit. If it does that, it seems to me to be far too restrictive. If, on the other hand, the expression `relevant to the committee's inquiry' includes not only evidence relevant to the question of whether a particular issue is more or less likely to have been the fact-if it is confined to that, then (9) should be expanded-but also the question of credit, I am quite happy with how it is expressed. Perhaps whoever sums up can tell me that.
—That's the point I'm making. That would presumably be a matter for determination of the committee.
—No, but if that particular paragraph binds us, then it is not. If that is what that means, if it is used in the restrictive sense, the committee will be stopped from doing that.
—The decision on what it means would be made according to the commonsense of the committee.

—Yes, but why did the honourable senator not put that in? I would be happy if he had put that in. If what he is saying is that all of this is to be left to the commonsense of the committee, clauses 9 and 10 have really said nothing. I hope that the committee has always exercised commonsense. If that is all it means, why have we got this elaborate display before us? That is what I want to know.

SPEECH.PARA: Paragraph (12), which has material which causes some concern to me, states:

Where a witness gives evidence reflecting adversely on a person and the committee is not satisfied that that evidence is relevant to the committee's inquiry, the committee shall give consideration to expunging that evidence from the transcript of evidence, and to forbidding the publication of that evidence.

I am quite happy to agree that evidence should not be published if it is not relevant. It seems to me that there are problems in expunging evidence from the transcript of evidence as such simply because the committee thinks it is not relevant and it reflects adversely on a person. The expunging of and the removal of evidence always seems to me to be fraught with danger because the committee then becomes able to label evidence in a particular way and to exclude and expunge evidence which may later become significant. Although (12) may have merit in exceptional cases, to state it as a general rule is dangerous. They are the comments I want to make on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I acknowledge that you and many other people have worked hard on this draft and in bringing this matter to this stage before the chamber. What we are discussing is important, and I would like to acknowledge the work that has been done not only by the senators who have been directly involved, but also by those responsible persons in the staff of the Senate who have the institution of the Senate at heart.

SPEECH.PARA: I briefly want to acknowledge what Senator Cooney said about paragraph (9) of proposed resolution 1, which is of concern to me also. It states:
A chairman of a committee shall take care to ensure that all questions put to witnesses are relevant to the committee's inquiry . . .

Let me give an example of this. If the Senate Select Committee on Video Material received evidence from, say, the former Commonwealth chief film censor-I am talking about Mrs Janet Strickland-and if one were to ask where she is now working, would that be a relevant matter? She happens to be working for one of the groups pushing videos which are the subject of the inquiry. I think that we are being too restrictive there. A polite question could be asked. I do not say that the witnesses who come before committees should be subjected to cross-examination or abuse. The chairman must ensure that that does not take place. But I think the point that has been raised by Senator Cooney is valid and I believe there should be an amendment made to address that issue.

I shall go through the proposed resolutions very quickly and raise the points that exercise my mind, and whoever is summing up may be able to address them. Paragraph (3) of proposed resolution 1 states:

A witness shall be given reasonable notice of a meeting at which the witness is to appear, and shall be supplied with a copy of the committee's order of reference, a statement of the matters expected to be dealt with during the witness's appearance . . .

It is my view that it may be difficult to determine what ought or ought not to go into the statement. I would have thought that a possible substitute for those words could be, `an outline of the subject headings expected to be dealt with'. That would probably enable the Committee secretariat and the Chairman of the Committee to define more clearly what is likely to be dealt with. I know that a statement of matters could encompass that, but if persons who were to appear as witnesses were given a list of the subject headings expected to be dealt with, that would not only assist those committee members but also focus their attention on the matters. Paragraph 1 (14) states:

A witness may make application to be accompanied by counsel and to consult counsel . . . In considering such an application, a committee shall have regard to the need for the witness to be accompanied by counsel to ensure the proper protection of the witness . . .

I assume that that means the proper legal protection, but it does not say that. If it means the proper legal protection, then it ought to say `the proper legal protection'. Paragraph (17) deals with the old problem which unfortunately enables many public servants appearing before Estimates committees to avoid answering questions. It states:
An officer of a department of the Commonwealth or of a State shall not be asked to give opinions on a matter of policy . . .
The Macquarie Dictionary definition of `policy' is as follows:
. . . a definite course of action adopted as expedient or from other considerations . . .

If, for example, the Department of Housing and Construction-or whatever it is now called-builds a building of one type instead of another type for another department, surely a decision of policy has been made by that department. It certainly should be required to explain such a policy. This paragraph does not say that it cannot do that and, on reflection, is quite proper, because officers cannot say, `It was a rotten decision made by my boss' and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are other ways that they communicate that information.

—Yes. If what we are talking about when we refer to opinions is clearly understood, that is okay by me. But departments are expected to explain to Estimates committees, public accounts committees or public works committees the policies they have made. Departments and the individuals in departments make a large number of policy decisions, if the definition of `policy' is the one I have just given. Paragraph (19) says:

SPEECH.PARA: Where a committee has any reason to believe that any person has been improperly influenced in respect of evidence . . .

I wonder whether that is precise enough. I am not sure what is meant by the words `improperly influenced' in that context. Maybe whoever is summing up can let us know. Maybe Senator Durack or Senator Cooney will let us know whether that phrase is meant in the context of threats or whether it could apply to a person who is, for example, coached by a public relations man or a solicitor. What do the words `improperly influenced' mean? It seems to me that the definition is pretty broad. I do not have any comment to make about resolution 2. Paragraph (b) of resolution 3 states:
the existence of any remedy other than that power for any act which may be held to be a contempt . . .

Does that mean that, if a person could sue, the contempt would be relegated? In other words, if a person has the option of suing, does that mean that no further action will be taken on the question of contempt? I acknowledge the force of what Senator Puplick and Senator Cooney said in respect of resolution 5 but, as Senator Durack said, there may not be anybody in the chamber who may respond on behalf of an individual who is aggrieved. We have to provide for those persons who do not have anybody in the chamber to respond on their behalf. That could be done in one of two ways: by appointing a member of the Senate as a type of ombudsman who would defend anybody who feels aggrieved by what has been said in the chamber, or, alternatively, by taking the course proposed in resolution 5. Again, I acknowledge the force of the argument put forward by Senator Puplick. However, I cannot see any way out of the situation other than that which is proposed by resolution 5.
Resolution 6 talks about interference with the Senate. Paragraph (1) states:
A person shall not improperly interfere with the free exercise by the Senate or a committee of its authority, or with the free performance by a Senator of the Senator's duties as a Senator.

That is pretty broad, but I suppose it does not mean that campaigns cannot be waged outside to defeat a senator for what he or she may have said in this chamber. No doubt that is not meant there. I note what is said in paragraph (3). I simply observe that, if that paragraph were to be taken as it is written, everybody would become an independent. We will see how that works out. It is a very interesting paragraph. Paragraph (4) deals with the molestation of senators. It states:
A person shall not inflict any punishment, penalty or injury upon, or deprive of any benefit, a Senator on account of the Senator's conduct as a Senator.

I suppose there is a legal background to all these things. I hope that there is a legal background to the words `deprive of any benefit'. The general populace in my electorate is perfectly entitled to deprive me of the benefit of sitting here if I do things which are not in accordance with its wishes. I refer lastly to resolution 10: `Reference to Senate proceedings in court proceedings'. Paragraph (1) removes the opportunity for a majority party to stall court proceedings by refusing leave of the Senate. It is to the credit of the persons who have drawn up these resolutions that they have foreseen such circumstances and have included that paragraph. On that laudatory note, I again congratulate those who have been involved in placing these very important matters before the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to touch on only one matter, which Senator Harradine mentioned in passing but which I think warrants a little more consideration; that is, resolution 6, `Matters constituting contempts' and, in particular, matters involving interference with the Senate. Paragraph (1) says:

SPEECH.PARA: A person shall not improperly interfere with the free exercise by the Senate or a committee of its authority, or with the free performance by a Senator of the Senator's duties as a Senator.
The following paragraphs list a series of elaborations, if you like, on the actions dealt with by that latter point; that is:
A person shall not . . . improperly interfere with the free . . . performance by a Senator of the Senator's duties as a Senator.
Paragraph (2) says:

A person shall not, by fraud, intimidation, force or threat of any kind, by the offer or promise of any inducement or benefit of any kind, or by other improper means, influence a Senator in the Senator's conduct as a Senator or induce a Senator to be absent from the Senate or a committee.

I would like to focus for a moment on the use of the words `fraud, intimidation, force or threat of any kind'. I make the observation that a senator's conduct includes the senator's power-indeed, the senator's duty-to vote in this place. The next point is headed `Senators seeking benefits, etc'. I will read only the relevant parts of this paragraph:

A Senator shall not . . . enter into any contract, understanding or arrangement having the effect, or which may have the effect, of controlling or limiting the Senator's independence or freedom of action as a Senator . . .
Paragraph (4), which is headed `Molestation of Senators', states:
A person shall not inflict any punishment, penalty or injury upon, or deprive of any benefit, a Senator on account of the Senator's conduct as a Senator.

I return to my first presumption, namely, that part of a senator's conduct is that senator's voting pattern and voting decision. Presumably, inducing an senator to be absent from the Senate or a committee is done in order, at least on some occasions, to prevent that senator from exercising a vote or making a statement of some kind.

I wonder where that leaves Government members who apparently willingly sign a pledge that makes them bound to vote according to the majority decision of the Caucus. The penalty for voting against a decision by Caucus on a piece of legislation is expulsion. Indeed, that happened to former Senator George Georges only a short while ago. He voted against the Government's legislation on the card, was expelled and lost his job. He lost his income, his position and his capacity to continue to act as a senator. It would seem to me that that fits neatly under the heading `molestation'. I cannot think of anything worse that somebody could do to a senator than expel him from the political party to which he belongs, forcing him to contest the next election as an Independent, with very little opportunity of being returned. That is surely deprivation of a benefit in anybody's mind, as is the fact that he was influenced-or at least the attempt was made to influence him-in his conduct as a senator. As with all other Australian Labor Party senators and members, that influence is a constant influence and a constant attempt-sadly, generally successful-to influence their vote in this chamber. I wonder what happens regarding this major political party that happens to be in government-but this form of behaviour applies, anyway-whose senators enter into a contract which may, and indeed does, have the effect of controlling or limiting their independence or freedom of action as a senator.

I would like to know precisely what we are going to do about this situation. If these matters relating to privilege which constitute contempt are passed, does that mean that we either release all Labor Party senators and members from any contract they entered into with the Labor Party, or do we move contempt proceedings against those people who have influenced them by intimidation, force or threat into making those contracts? If so, whom do we charge with this contempt? Certainly it is easy enough as far as paragraph (3) is concerned. If the senator enters into a contract which may have the effect of controlling or limiting the senator's independence or freedom of action as a senator, somebody can be specified as having acted in a manner constituting contempt. But in the case of former Senator Georges, to whom do we direct the action? If the answer is that we cannot pin it on a specific individual and we have to let the situation continue, then this item in the report is very sadly lacking. Essentially, we are saying that no outside person-that is, no non-political party person-can act improperly in this way, can attempt to influence a senator's conduct as a senator, can attempt to influence the way that senator votes or speaks, either in this chamber or on a committee. We will not allow an outsider to do that but we are perfectly happy to allow a majority of senators, wilfully and willingly, to do it to themselves or allow others to do it to them.

It seems to me pretty appalling that we are making a set of rules for one set of people that we are apparently not willing to, or perhaps able to, apply to a significant proportion of people in this place. It is particularly important when we remember that allegedly-although, sadly it is a disappearing element in this place-the Senate is supposed to be a States House. It should therefore not have its members intimidated, threatened, forced or allowed to enter into any contract of their own volition which restricts them from exercising the very role they were elected for-that is, to look at legislation on its merits and if the Senate's origins are to be believed, according to its effect on their State of origin. If they do not perform their duty as senators, they are no longer able to conduct themselves as senators, they are unable to act independently or with freedom as senators. If they attempt to do that, they are punished, a penalty is applied and they are deprived of a benefit which, again, is an item of contempt under paragraph (4).

As I said before, it is something of an outrage if resolution 6 in the document that we are discussing relates, refers and applies only to people outside this chamber, outside the Parliament as a whole, outside the political party system and does not apply to us as lawmakers. It is appalling that we should make something a contempt for other people and then allow ourselves to be exempt from it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly in this privileges debate to discuss the fifth resolution-the protection of persons referred to in the Senate. I support the resolution-particularly the amendment proposed by Senator Durack-but I am apprehensive about the system. I agree with a great deal of what Senator Puplick and Senator Cooney have said. But, on balance, it is better to try the new system to see how it works out. We have a system whereby the President, as Senator Puplick said, makes a decision. Traditionally, parliamentarians use a common-sense approach, but of course they are politically biased. If someone on one side of the political spectrum is dubbed, a parliamentarian will usually raise the issue in the ordinary parliamentary process. That system has worked reasonably well. I acknowledge that the defamation laws in Australia are inadequate and so that is an additional problem that is injected into any discussion of parliamentary privilege. Resolution 5 (1) (a) states:

SPEECH.PARA: claiming that the person has been adversely affected in reputation or in respect of dealings or associations with others, or injured in occupation, trade, office of financial credit, or that the person's privacy has been unreasonably invaded, by reason of that reference to the person;

That is a very comprehensive definition. I do not dispute that it has got to be a comprehensive definition. I am concerned that it might be possible for those who are well off and who can employ lawyers easily to take this issue into another political domain; in other words, the Privileges Committee could be in constant session. That is my concern.

I am also concerned that senators represent a cross-section of people with human weaknesses. The history of their sitting on the Privileges Committee has shown them to be a commonsense group of people in their deliberations. I am concerned-I have had this experience as Chairman of the Privileges Committee-that skilled lawyers can turn what would ordinarily be a sensible meeting into a farce. It will curb some of the excesses that I have seen perpetrated on these witnesses when the Committee, as a non-legal body, has tried to be reasonably fair to people coming before it. My main concern is how this will work in practice. I think all the potential is there for people who wish to exploit the system to turn it into a farce. On balance I think it is probably necessary for us to see how it works out. After this has been put in operation I reserve my right to come back and say whether it is a successful way of dealing with these problems. TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 18 deals with the monetary limit in property proceedings with which a magistrates court can deal. The Bill as originally drafted allowed magistrates courts to deal with property cases involving property of a certain value according to the amount specified in the State civil debt jurisdictions. That would have meant that different magistrates courts in different States would have been able to deal with cases involving property valued at different amounts. The Government's amendment seeks to impose a $20,000 ceiling on the value of property in contested property proceedings that can be heard in the magistrates court. The Opposition proposes to move an amendment seeking to lower that ceiling to $10,000. It is probably worth while to examine the different monetary limits imposed in the various States on property matters that can be heard in their respective civil debt jurisdictions; as well as the intentions of the various States in the coming year or so.

SPEECH.PARA: In New South Wales the current limit on the civil debt jurisdiction of magistrates courts is $5,000. Although that is the current limit, a Bill that raises that limit to $10,000, and $20,000 where a car is involved, has still to receive royal assent, although royal assent may have been granted in the intervening period since I received these statistics. In Victoria the amount is $20,000, and I understand that a Bill to raise that amount to $40,000 is at present before the Legislative Council of the Victorian Parliament. Under the provisions of the Queensland Magistrates Courts Act, the limit is $5,000, although there is a proposal to increase that limit to $20,000 next year. In South Australia the limit is $7,500, but I understand that an amendment that has been passed but not yet proclaimed raises that limit to $20,000. Under the Tasmanian Local Courts Act, the limit is $5,000. To the best of my knowledge there is no immediate plan to increase that amount.

I shall leave Western Australia out of it for the moment because, as with most other matters dealing with family law, Western Australia is a special case. The present limit in the Northern Territory is $10,000, and that amount is to be increased next year. However, I do not know to what level it is to be increased. In the Australian Capital Territory the limit is $10,000, with drafting instructions apparently in train to increase that amount to $50,000. I do not know whether that says something about the wealth of people who live in the Australian Capital Territory as distinct from people anywhere else or whether the relative value placed on that worth is so vastly different from what other States are looking at. Roughly speaking, most States are looking at upping the ante to $20,000. Presumably, the Government has chosen that level for that reason. However, there are enough variations on that to make some alternative proposal viable. I would have thought it a reasonable compromise to look at the situation in New South Wales.

We are dealing with a relatively small group of people, that is, people whose property distribution is valued at quite small amounts of money-$10,000 in the case of the Liberal amendment and $20,000 in the case of Labor's amendment to its own Bill. We are looking in the main at people who are renting, because if they owned their own property they would be outside the ambit of this legislation. Nevertheless, $10,000 is a very small amount when one takes into account the value of the goods in the home, and is a particularly small amount if the family owns one or more cars. The word `owns' is usually a euphemism because in most cases the finance company owns most of the car. Nevertheless, in most cases there will be a car around.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would the car be owned if it could be taken over?

—I suppose that, if the car was to be taken over, I would have to ask the Minister whether the case of a car not fully owned, not fully paid for, falls into the property to be distributed. I would have assumed that the debt would transfer to whoever was prepared to take the car on or whoever was granted the car. Perhaps before I pursue the matter I could have some response to that from the Government. I would have thought that one would run into the same problem with a house which has a mortgage over it but which nevertheless has an ascribed value.

—I am advised that, if the car were allocated to one of the parties, that would normally carry the debt with it. But it is open to the judge perhaps to vary that and say that the other party should make a contribution or indeed even pay all the instalments.

—There has been a misunderstanding. If we are talking about a magistrates court deciding on the distribution of property, it is the Government's intention, as indeed it is the intention of everybody in this place, to put a limit on the value of that property. The question that arose between Senator Durack and me related to what amounts to the value. Is a house worth $100,000 as part of the property settlement, if there is still an outstanding mortgage of $60,000, or is it worth only $40,000 because of the outstanding amount still to be paid? At this level, whether the figure is $10,000 or $20,000 or the New South Wales alternative of $10,000 or $20,000 if a car is involved, how do we determine that value? That is a pertinent matter in view of Senator Durack's comments. If the car is worth $11,000 but the finance company is still owed $9,000, are we saying that there is $2,000 or $11,000 involved.

—In Government amendment No. 8 it is intended that the gross value be taken less the lien, mortgage, charge or whatever might exist in relation to that property. In other words, one takes gross value. This is for the purpose of setting the level at which the jurisdiction of the magistrate to deal with the property matter cannot be contested. In other words, it sets the limit for the jurisdiction.
—Your amendment seems to be the reverse.
—I said that one takes gross value and does not take into account the charge, lien, mortgage or whatever.

—Is the Minister saying that if the car is worth $11,000, whether bought yesterday and that sum was paid for it or whether the car was bought 10 years ago and its retail value is $11,000, the figure of $11,000 is taken as the value in this clause?
—If one takes the next amendment with it, yes.

—I thank the Minister. —It is the market value at the time the court is considering the matter, which would be a valuation, I suppose, undertaken by those experienced in that sort of valuation-auctioneers and so on.
—It is the depreciated value, in essence.
—It is the market value.
—Yes. Well, it is the market value at that time.

—If there is some value that may depend on market forces, it may have been a higher value than the one originally paid. Let us hope that nobody has a Van Gogh in the garret, or he will be in big trouble under this provision.

SPEECH.PARA: The other likely event is that this car will be under hire purchase. I interjected on Senator Haines because I was not sure whether that would apply to a car under hire purchase. TALK.START.PARA: —Before the Minister elaborates on that, could I add to what Senator Durack has just asked and question where the ownership of the car actually does reside under law if the car is being paid off by a couple or an individual. TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise today an item with regard to overseas student policy. The Government announced in its Green Paper on higher education a review of overseas student policy in response to:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . some criticisms about various aspects of aid, foreign policy and administrative features of the subsidised program.
The Government's Green Paper says:
. . . any changes to the conditions of entry of new students that result will be implemented from 1990.

It certainly would not be unreasonable, I think, to argue that the days of the subsidised student program are numbered. I understand that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mr Hayden, is keen to see the overseas student program feature simply full-fee marketed courses on a commercial basis, plus government to gov- ernment scholarships via the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau.

Certainly it may be argued, of course, that a subsidised private student program cannot be sustained long in its present form. The overseas student charge is now so high that it probably does prevent students from poorer backgrounds from undertaking a course in any Australian institution, while it still gives a hefty subsidy to students from wealthier backgrounds who can afford full-fee courses. But it can also be argued from the point of view of Australia's foreign interests, on the grounds of the promotion of international student mobility and on human rights grounds, that there should be still some mechanism within the overseas student program that provides a generous subsidy to private overseas students-that is, students who are not nominees of their government.

If this Government is intent on doing away with the subsidised overseas student program in its present form, I suggest that a system of scholarships provided to private overseas students by individual higher education institutions, as a result of extra funds from the Government, would return opportunities for an Australian education to students from poorer backgrounds, ensure that large numbers continued to study in this country from overseas, and be in harmony with our foreign policy interests.

One of the by-products of Australia's overseas student program is its contribution towards easing racial tension in a number of countries-in particular racial tension in Malaysia. Thousands of young Malay, Chinese and Indian students have been able to study in this country and undertake higher education which would otherwise be denied to them in their own country as a result of the discriminatory policies of the Malay dominated government. If we do not provide that opportunity, I suggest that the resentment felt by Chinese and Indians towards the indigenous Malays is likely to increase. I do not think I have to remind the Senate of the situation that occurred towards the end of last year, and it is still continuing, whereby large numbers of Malay politicians, particularly those from Opposition parties, were placed under detention. They remain under detention, some of them being detained under the Security Act for up to two years. This is a situation, of course, which means that people can be detained by government decree, without trial, for two years. Undoubtedly there is a racial problem in Malaysia, but Australia's engaging in an exercise with regard to its foreign aid program mindless of that particular racial tension I think would be not only to the detriment of Malaysia but also to the detriment in a very important way of Australia's foreign interests.

Almost all Malay, Chinese and Indians who have entered Australia to study have in fact undertaken their study here and returned to their own country. If we now look at the higher education fee, the overseas student charge, it increased in 1985 to 32 per cent or 45 per cent of the full average cost of a course, that amount being the amount the Government maintains is the cost of a full student within our institutions. It is not, by the way, the amount of money the Government is providing for the recent new places. Interestingly enough there is another bit of hypocrisy which floats around there and that is that the new places are funded at $3,000 to $4,000 and overseas students are charged at the nominal rate of $10,000. So while the Government says an overseas student costs $10,000, it is only funding new places for Australian students at $3,000 to $4,000.

I think we have to acknowledge the situation in Malaysia. It is a distressing situation for those people who know the country and who are hopeful that that country will continue in the democratic tradition. There has been, of course, in recent times the added problem of the Supreme Court of Malaysia ruling that the current ruling party is illegal. The ruling party there is not only a political party but also a major landowner, a major developer and the owner of some of the most prestigious properties in Kuala Lumpur. The current government party is basically a federation of a number of other parties: a Chinese party, an Indian party and a Malay party. It was hoped that by that method there could be a move forward, in an area which I am not trying to suggest is anything other than difficult. It is therefore very important for Australia to consider carefully any implications for that situation in Malaysia with regard to the overseas student charge.

The program is undoubtedly now in jeopardy. We have moved from providing a more generous level of support to providing support only for those children of wealthy families. I think that Australia has to look again at how it might give support, and the suggestion I wish to put forward is that the current subsidy be provided directly to the institutions. The institutions then would be able to provide scholarships on the basis of merit. I understand that there would be, even if that scheme were fully adopted, still a government to government program, but with Malaysia, at present, that government to government program involves almost exclusively Malays. I believe that if the institutions had the opportunity, by way of scholarship, to support overseas students we would be making a major contribution to levelling out, in some way, the people who are able to come to Australia and partake of study here.

I had the opportunity towards the end of last year to be in Kuala Lumpur for a Commonwealth Parliamentary Association conference. It was very interesting to hear from Malaysian politicians-and we were there on Independence Day so we had the chance to mingle with many people, not only from the Federal Parliament but also from the provincial parliaments-that they hold Australia very dear. One is astounded by the number of politicians in Malaysia who studied in Australia, who return to Australia for their holidays, who bring their families to Australia for holidays and who have very fond memories of this country. In other words, if one looks at the current context one sees the results of the money that our community has spent in the past on educating students from other countries. One sees that that is paying off. If one really wants to be selfish about it, in terms of dollar for dollar benefits, and not look at it as part of our international obligation, one could very well sustain an argument that we have got back more than we have put in with regard to the education of overseas students. Our ability to trade with Malaysia is based on that very warm understanding between the people who are in power and in positions of influence in Malaysia and their counterparts here in Australia.

I would urge the Government, therefore, not to put aside lightly the current program without looking, in terms of its replacement, at this issue of racial tensions in Malaysia and making sure that any replacement for the current program does not exacerbate the problem in that country, with which we have very warm and enduring relationships, but assists that country to move forward in solving that very difficult problem. At the same time we should urge the Malaysian Government to move on the institution of a more vigorous parliamentary democracy. I believe that the ingredients are there within the country, the goodwill is there within the country, and there are many people who wish that that will be the future for Malaysia. I think this country has an obligation to make sure that in any task we undertake we do not get in the way of a successful resolution of the racial conflict in Malaysia and its development as a thriving and vigorous democracy within our region.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address during this lunchtime matters of public interest debate a very important event-important not only to the individuals who participated in it but important to the skills and the future of our nation. At a time when a lot of attention is being given to the results of the Winter Olympics currently being held in Canada, I am going to refer to the results of another set of Olympic Games, these ones held this time in Australia. It is unfortunate, and indeed an indictment on the media of this country, that the media have not given this particular event its fair share of coverage, because it is an extremely important event. I am referring of course, Mr Acting Deputy President, as you yourself would know, to the 1988 International Youth Skill Olympics. Reports in this morning's papers indicated that the youth of Australia have done particularly well in this competition. Out of 34 skill classifications, Australia won four gold medals, five silver medals and three bronze medals-by far and away the best Australia has ever done in this competition.

SPEECH.PARA: It is only the third occasion on which we have competed in the competition. The first was in Austria in 1983, when we finished in tenth place with 12 young competitors. In Japan in 1985 we had an 18-member team and we won gold in bricklaying, and we won also two silver medals and three bronze medals. We were placed equal fifth. On this occasion we have won 12 medals, as I said, and we were placed third in the competition placings, behind Korea and Taiwan.

I had the pleasure, and the very rewarding experience, of being able to visit the Youth Skill Olympics in Sydney last Saturday morning, in company with three fellow members of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. You yourself, Mr Acting Deputy President, were there, and like me were enthralled with the skills on display and the enthusiasm of the young people who were taking part in the competition. This competition is the culmination of a whole series of events in which some 4,000 individual young people of Australia took part over the last two years. They competed in 30 regional competitions leading up to the Skill Olympics, the results of which were announced yesterday.

Nineteen nations competed, and these Skill Olympics have been far and away the most successful to be held. As I said earlier in my speech, there were some 34 skill classifications, ranging from bricklaying through to computer numerically controlled machining, fitting, gas welding, plumbing, stonemasonry, jewellery, ladies hairdressing, men's hairdressing and a range of other trades. I think it is a commendation for Australia that we were able to reach the high standing we did reach, and indeed it is a tribute to the organisers of this event, to the participants and to their managers.

In mentioning how we went, I would also draw attention to the emphasis that other nations place on this competition. As I said earlier, this is only the third time that we have participated in the Skill Olympics, and we have done particularly well, but it is the twenty-ninth occasion that the competition has been held. One nation giving a great deal of attention to the competition is Ireland. Ireland, a tiny nation with a population actually smaller than Sydney, the city in which the competition was held, outlaid some three-quarters of a million Irish pounds, around $2m, to send 18 people across to these Olympics. They came out of the competition with four medals-two gold, one silver and one bronze. Ireland has a reputation going back to medieval days of being the island of saints and scholars. I do not want to dwell too much on the saintly part of it, but on the scholarly part of it I am proud to say that the country retains its emphasis on the education of its youth. It is known within Europe that the youth of Ireland are the youngest, most highly educated group of young people in Europe. That in itself is a commendation for that nation which, like Australia, is suffering very severe economic pressures. Despite those economic pressures, Ireland has outlaid a substantial amount of money. Although $2m may not be a great amount of money in terms of the Australian Budget, to a small nation like Ireland it is a tremendous amount of money. It shows the emphasis that this small nation is putting on the education of its youth.

Leading up to the Skill Olympics, we have had a competition known as Work Skill Australia, held over 30 regions of Australia. Some 532 young people participated in 42 skill categ- ories. Over the whole of the competition, 4,000 young people took part. The organisation for this event was done mainly by volunteers-volunteers from industry, from government departments and from the trade union movement. This is an excellent example of what co-operation can do. I would be pleased to provide any honourable senator, or indeed anybody else, with a list of the people who made contributions to this magnificent event.

In conclusion, I would like to place on the record, on behalf of the Senate, our congratulations to the people who organised the event, the people who supported our youth all the way through the competitions, and there was a range of them, and the individual winners. You, Mr Acting Deputy President, would be interested to know that three of the four of this country's gold medal winners actually came from your home State of Queensland. I am sure you will be doing something in your own way to congratulate them. Our gold medal winners were, in the bricklaying field, Stephen Perryman, from Armidale in New South Wales; in automotive mechanics, Devin Flor, from Mackay in Queensland; in plant mechanics, Mark Eddison, from Highfields in Queensland; and in the industrial wiring category, Russell Cooper from Gladstone in Queensland. I think all honourable senators would join me in wishing these people every congratulations on their success and every good wish for their future.
