TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to deal at this particular time with two matters which are essentially unrelated except that they are both relevant to the activities of the Australian Labor Party in New South Wales. I wish to draw the attention of the Senate to additional information which has not been canvassed before concerning how Mr Stephen Loosley dealt with the Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd cheque for $10,000. The excuses that we have been given are that it was sloppy, that it was an honest mistake. One could almost say that `sloppy and honest mistake' has become the new motto of the Labor Party in Australia, particularly in New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, those excuses just do not stand up to scrutiny. When we look at the facts we see that there is room for further alarm. The facts are these: in New South Wales electoral funding legislation was introduced in 1981, and section 83 of that legislation provides that, within 90 days of the day for the return of the writs for a general election, a declaration of political contributions received and electoral expenditure incurred during the period commencing on the day following the polling day for the previous general election and ending on the polling day for the current election has to be made. All moneys received have to be disclosed. There is only one exception to that rule, and that is moneys which are received and which have been expressly given and used solely for the purpose of an election for a legislature not being in New South Wales.

In the event that the cheque had been properly dealt with and banked in New South Wales as a political donation for electoral purposes, it would still have had to have been disclosed in the 1987 New South Wales return under the Federal legislation. Under the New South Wales legislation even if it had been banked for maintenance purposes it would still have had to have been disclosed as having been received between the two elections.

However, in May 1987 the Labor Government in New South Wales introduced a new Bill. It introduced a Bill to amend the Election Funding Act, to change the necessity for all contributions to be disclosed, whether for maintenance or for electoral purposes, to the position where only those donations received for electoral purposes need be disclosed. The timetable for this particular incident is very relevant. The Bill was introduced on 13 May, the second reading debate took place on 28 May, on 29 May the Bill was guillotined through-in fact Mr Booth, from the Liberal Party, was in mid-sentence when he was cut off-and the Bill was assented to on 16 June. It is interesting, of course, that the Harris-Daishowa letter was dated 11 June. It was received by Mr Young in his office on 14 June, and up until that point had it been received in New South Wales its disclosure would have been required. But on 16 June, when the Bill was assented to, the necessity to disclose that money, if it was used for maintenance purposes and if it had been given for maintenance purposes, no longer existed. Mr Loosley wrote on 24 June acknowledging receipt of the cheque and saying it was used for maintenance purposes. But of course one cannot convert the intention of the donor by trying to say that it is to be used for a different purpose.

It is most interesting to note, Mr Acting Deputy President, that today on the midday news Mr Unsworth announced that Mr Stephen Loosley's name will no longer be used as the authorisation of the commercials for the ALP's political advertising. So it is most significant to look at the timetable over which those events took place. Today Senator Short and shadow Attorney-General Reith have called upon the Government to do all it can to have the report on this matter released. It is indeed an important matter.

The second matter I want to deal with is also a scandal in New South Wales, and it relates directly to the Richmond report. For those honourable senators who are not aware of what the Richmond report is, it is a report dealing with the closing of schedule 5 hospitals in New South Wales; that is, hospitals where people who have a mental disability have had hospital care hitherto. I think I might have mentioned on a previous occasion that I recently listened to the parent of somebody who had, in his words, been kicked out of a schedule 5 hospital, and he asked that the Ministers who kicked his daughter out also be kicked out.

This story relates to what happens to the Richmond rejects. It is a story which relates to a Bondi boarding house. This boarding house, as a result of two-thirds of the schedule 5 hospitals being closed, has become one of those places where people who no longer have a home are ending up. With people spilling out of shelters for the homeless, they are having to go to places such as this. The Bondi Lodge, at 63 Fletcher Street, Bondi, is a boarding house allegedly for old and poor as well as mentally disabled people who have been thrown out of hospitals because of the Richmond report. It is currently not licensed by the New South Wales Department of Youth and Community Services as a residence for handicapped persons. It houses approximately 95 people and Waverley Council has notified the owner of overcrowding on at least one occasion.

The owner since September 1987 is one Michael Lenin. The manager is one Simon Coleman. Simon Coleman is a man who is known to the Department of Health as a manager of such boarding houses and has been frequently in breach of licensing requirements in the past. Officers in the Department of Youth and Community Services have recommended, I am advised, that Coleman be taken to court for failing to apply for a licence for the Bondi Lodge. The Department has given him until April to meet the licensing requirements. It is alleged that he is known to use violence on some of the boarders.

A description of the premises is pretty awful. It is overcrowded, with some rooms having as many as eight beds in a room and where both men and women sleep in that same room. There is only one very small common room, with broken chairs and where large tins are used for ashtrays. The carpet and the other coverings are worn and torn. The stairs are steep, with dangerous coverings; bathrooms and toilets are rarely cleaned; mould and grime are everywhere. People who are living upstairs complain of the leaking roof. The premises are rarely cleaned. There is poor quality food; residents complain of rotten fruit and vegetables. The bedding is rarely changed, the fire doors are usually locked and there are sanitation problems. Mr Acting Deputy President, I do have photocopies of photographs of that boarding house, and I seek leave to table those photocopies.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —When patients come out of schedule 5 hospitals, where they have had their medicines monitored, and go into a place like the Bondi Lodge, there is no way they can have someone supervise that medication. These people are paying anything up to $100 a week to live in these seamy conditions. But the point that has to be made is that this problem has been caused by the actions of the Unsworth Government, closing the schedule 5 hospitals and throwing those people out-kicking them out, in the words of the Italian father I mentioned earlier. They are being kicked out and they have nowhere to go, so these are the premises which become the dosshouses of the streets of the city of Sydney.

SPEECH.PARA: The New South Wales Liberal Party, the alternative Government for New South Wales, has said that it will not sell the nine psychiatric schedule 5 hospitals; that it will look after those people who are disabled and psychiatrically ill; that they will have proper and decent treatment; that proper action will be taken to make sure that people do not have to live in these deplorable conditions; and that an action of government should not result in a lessening of the quality of life of people who, through no fault of their own, have become a burden that they themselves cannot deal with.

I have dealt with two matters which I have said are unrelated in subject matter, except for the close nexus that they have with the operations of the Labor Party in New South Wales. It is indeed most important to bring to the Senate's attention the timetable setting out the way the law in New South Wales was changed with the knowledge of the ALP and the ALP machine; the way that the cheque was dealt with after that particular date; the fact that Mr Unsworth has seen fit to remove Loosley's name from advertising; and the fact that the Government that says it is concerned about going back to basics has no care or compassion for people who have no way of looking after themselves. The Labor Party, in New South Wales in particular, stands condemned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, the matter that I wish to raise today under the heading `Matters of Public Interest' certainly is of interest to many of my constituents. It is a matter which I raised previously this week, by way of a question, and in the Estimates committee hearings last year; that is: what is going to be the fate of many former public servants who are in receipt of compensation with the new arrangements that the Government intends to bring in? It is a matter which is causing great anxiety to many people I would think throughout Australia but particularly in my electorate. Public servants in receipt of compensation, who are very unsure of their future while the Government continues to hedge, are not able to get straight answers about what will happen to them in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, I asked at an Estimates committee hearing on 8 October 1987 when information would be available about the proposed changes. That was October, but that was many months after people had known there were to be changes and had been trying to get answers. I was told then:
It is possible that legislation might be introduced in the current sittings-
that is, the last Budget sittings-
or in the next sittings. There are still some decisions to be taken on the matter, but consideration of the detail is at a very advanced stage. In fact, drafting has commenced.

That was last October. I wonder why, then, when it is almost six months later, that all questions about this matter are met with a stoney silence from the Ministers involved. I refer again to the question I put to the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) on 22 February, asking whether he could at least give an assurance that those who are on compensation will not be retrospectively disadvantaged by the new arrangements. It seemed to me that it was not unreasonable to ask for that assurance, especially as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is seeking to defuse the superannuation issue by saying that there will be no retrospective operation of the new legislation affecting superannuation. He said that presumably to keep things under control for the New South Wales election.

I wonder, then, why he will not give such an assurance as far as former public servants in receipt of compensation are concerned. Perhaps the problem is that there just are not enough of them in New South Wales for the Government to feel that it is a matter of any consequence. I think the line is wearing a bit thin when daily there are news reports, some of them going into great detail, of what is proposed in the legislation. There has been some consultation, so the extent of the changes is fairly well known. I refer to the article in today's Canberra Times, which sets out in considerable detail the numbers of people likely to be affected and the arrangements which are to be put in place. I would say to the Government, `Are these proposals now published correct or are they not? Will you give us a straight answer and if not, why not? What conclusions are people entitled to draw from the fact that you will not confirm or deny what is very widely known to be the case at the present time?'.

The statements contained in today's paper are very consistent with information given to me almost a year ago by people who are vitally interested in this area. As we know from the statement given last October, the drafting had commenced at that time and the decisions were at a very advanced stage. I think we are entitled to say, `Are these matters correct? If not, in what respect are they incorrect?'. It is clear that the scheme is slowly coming to light, and I would say to the Government it is time it told us exactly what was happening to alleviate the uncertainty. It seems clear that there will be a number of people retrospectively affected if the proposal which has been talked about goes through. I challenge the Government to give an assurance that it will not put people who have worked for the Government, who have been loyal public servants, who have had to retire-most of them most reluctantly-in a position where, not being able to go back into the work force, they may have their situation affected and be less well off than they would have been. I want an assurance that those who are on compensation will not lose their present entitlements. New arrangements for others, by all means, and if the Government is going to put into effect new arrangements which will benefit people already on compensation that is fine but I want an assurance that it will not proceed with any aspect of the legislation that will make them worse off.

There is also talk of removing from public servants the right to sue at common law-an absolutely fundamental right. I would like also an assurance that that right will not be taken away from people who have worked, many of them for all their working lives, for the Commonwealth; that they will not be deprived of the opportunity that that entails; and that their families will not be deprived of the opportunity to benefit in a way they would have benefited had they not been injured and had to give up their employment. When people go onto compensation they lose the opportunity to proceed and advance up the scale to earn more, to get more satisfying jobs and have their families to benefit from that.

So there are questions which are causing great concern to many of my constituents. I have raised the matter of compensation several times; it is being reported in the newspapers frequently and it is time that the Government gave a clear statement so that the uncertainty that many are suffering is removed and they can get on with their lives knowing what the future holds for them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to finish comments I was making on Tuesday night about my motivations for committing civil disobedience, but before I do that I feel obliged to set the record straight for people who were somewhat surprised by Senator Walsh's divulgence that I had once been a member of the Country Party. How boring it is of him to keep trotting out that old line-which he did not have the guts to do while I was in the chamber; he waited until I had left. Yes, it is true: I was once a member of the Country Party. I was a farmer's daughter, living in a country town, and I was aged 17. The Country Party offered some social life and the opportunity to practise debating-I must say usually on very frivolous topics. So I joined the Country Party and the Junior Farmers. I was in the Country Party for about 18 months. I am not ashamed of that, but it is important to note that I left the Country Party long before I became of voting age, so I never voted for the Country Party, which was part of the coalition which committed Australia to participating in the Vietnam war. In fact I participated in the Vietnam moratorium movement although I was not in the forefront of the organisation. My political activism, centred around grassroots community movements for social change, began in earnest in 1978 after a period of several years overseas.

SPEECH.PARA: I challenge all senators and members to check back to their political affiliations at age 17 and consider the changes made by many people as they cross the political spectrum. For example, Don Chipp, Liberal Minister for the Navy during the Vietnam war, changed sides completely to become one of Australia's most ardent and respected antinuclear campaigners. People do have changes of heart and ought to be credited for that-if they have moved towards a more enlightened position. Some swap sides for opportunistic reasons. Look at members of our present Cabinet; consider the radical views and level of activism of some of them in their student days and see where they are now-on the right hand edge of a very conservative so-called Labor Government. At least I have moved in what I consider to be an ideologically sound direction. It is a good feeling to be radicalised with age instead of pragmatised.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might be a sign of senility.

—I do not think I have reached that stage yet. To get back to what I was saying about civil disobedience, I was using the Pine Gap connection as my rationale for committing civil disobedience. I pointed out that Pine Gap is crucial to the United States nuclear war fighting capabilities because of its functions in receiving and transmitting information and the use of that information for tracking and targeting sites within the Soviet Union-functions to which our Government will not admit. So the United States base in the middle of Australia is used to plan strategies for fighting either a nuclear or a conventional war. I believe that to be immoral and I believe it to be wrong for the Australian Government to continually deceive the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a great deal of speculation about other disturbing aspects of Pine Gap's operations-the role of the United States National Security Agency and the role of the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA), which uses Pine Gap as a listening post to spy on allies, including us, as well as enemies. This includes allegations made by Christopher Boyce, convicted in the United States for treason, who claimed that the CIA was spying on Australia and deceiving Australia on a regular basis. His allegations have never been disproved.

The very existence of Pine Gap is offensive to hundreds of thousands of Australians on other grounds as well. Firstly, it makes a nuclear target out of the people of Alice Springs, a fact which the Australian Government admits to but is prepared to accept-very strange indeed, and not of very much comfort to the people of Alice Springs, who must be considered expendable in the event of nuclear war. Secondly, it is an abrogation of Australia's sovereignty. There is an embarrassing history of Australian ignorance about what goes on at Pine Gap, even at prime ministerial level. John Gorton did not have a clue what was going on there, and did not seem to care, either. Thirdly, it is a denial of the rights of Aboriginals and other Australians to a huge chunk of territory in the middle of the Australian landscape. It is a violation of Aboriginal links with the land and a desecration of the living heart of our country.

The overriding objection remains, however, that Pine Gap is a crucial part of the United States war machine. It is the eyes and ears of the United States military command. It ties Australia into actions which are immoral, illegal and insane. Preventing its use for these negative purposes therefore becomes a moral obligation. Raising public awareness about the real functions of the base is vitally important. There is still a great deal about Pine Gap which is secret but more people are asking questions. Ultimately, the Government must provide some answers. Civil disobedience is an important part of the educative process for the wider public. As I said previously, Nuremberg obliges us to act. While we have the freedom of choice to act in this manner, I believe it is encumbent upon us to ensure that our Government is not involved in such immoral acts as preparation for genocide.

Civil disobedience is a statement of commitment to the prevention of the greatest catastrophe imaginable, the use of nuclear weapons. Some people criticise me as a senator for getting involved in this last resort method. They say to me, `You are meant to be a law maker, not a law breaker'. In answer to that I can only say that my conscience demands me above all to seek the truth non-violently. Gandhi put it very well:
There are moments in your life when you must act. The still small voice within must always be the final arbiter when there is a conflict of duty.
Sitting suspended from 1.32 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Attorney-General, and it is about the Solicitor-General's opinion on the Blewett affair. Who gave the Solicitor-General his instructions? When were the instructions given? What was in the brief given to the Solicitor-General? Will the Minister table the brief? Will any further opinions or reports from either the Solicitor-General, the police or the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) also be tabled at the appropriate time? Finally, in view of the fact that a police report has been called for, why was the Solicitor-General's opinion sought before all of the facts had been collected?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked the Solicitor-General to prepare an opinion in this matter, and I did so late on the evening of-I forget the exact date, but I think it was two nights ago; in other words the night of the statement by Dr Blewett to the House of Representatives chamber.
—Before or after he spoke?

—After he spoke in the chamber. It was very late at night-it might have been about 11 o'clock or something like that-that we tried to contact Dr Gavan Griffith. The fact is that there is no written request by me, or brief, in that sense. What I asked Dr Gavan Griffith to supply was an opinion on the matters in issue relating to the communication from the Health Insurance Commission to the office of the Minister for Community Services and Health, and in turn from his office to the honourable member for Canning, of certain material relating to medical services profiles. I provided to the Solicitor-General the text of the statement made in the House of Representatives by the Minister for Community Services and Health and the minute dated 7 January 1988 from the General Manager of the Health Insurance Commission to the Minister for Community Services and Health. I believe that document had been tabled during the course of Dr Blewett's statement to the House of Representatives.

ANSWER.PARA: The relevant statute appeared to be the Health Insurance Act 1973, but I then asked the Solicitor-General to advise on the position of the Minister in relation to that matter on the basis of the material contained in those documents, namely, Dr Blewett's statement to the House of Representatives and the minute of 7 January 1988.

The honourable senator asked whether any further reports of the Australian Federal Police or the DPP will be tabled. The answer remains that which I gave, I think, in the course of a matter of public importance (MPI) earlier this week on a different investigation being carried out by the Australian Federal Police, and that was that the Australian Federal Police, having carried out its investigation and having compiled a report, make an assessment of whether an offence has been committed or not, but pass that report to the Director of Public Prosecutions. It is then, as I said to the Senate chamber during that MPI, for the DPP to determine, in his quite unfettered discretion and independently of any political pressure whatsoever-and, of course, that is why he was given the great autonomy and independence of his office by this Parliament-when he decides there should not be a prosecution, whether reasons should be given. I suppose that if he decides that a prosecution should go ahead, once again the report would not be made available because the whole matter would then be sub judice.

The honourable senator asked: In view of the fact that a police report had been called for, why was the Solicitor-General's opinion sought? It was sought to enable the Prime Minister to discharge his responsibilities as the Leader of the Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Attorney-General. I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that on 9 March 1973, listed on page 2824 of the Queensland Hansard, volume 261, as the then member for Everton, I asked the following question of the then Minister for Works and representing Police, Max Hodges:

QUESTION.PARA: Was the Crime Intelligence Unit warned six weeks ago that the bombing of restaurants and night clubs was to take place in this State and that after the Torino club had been bombed Whiskey Au Go Go would be the next.

The answer from Minister Hodges was `no'. I now ask the Minister whether he can advise the Senate of the contents of the Commonwealth Police advice to the Queensland Police concerning the possibility of a fire at the Whiskey Au Go Go nightclub. To whom was that advice given and under what circumstances was it made available? Did the Acting Commissioner of the Queensland Police, or the now retired police officer Sid Atkinson, or any person, have access to that advice?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised by the Australian Federal Police that on 26 February 1973 the Commonwealth Police in Brisbane received information through an informant that two brothers in Sydney were making threats against certain clubs and that they intended to fire bomb the Whiskey Au Go Go nightclub in Brisbane. On 27 February 1973 two Commonwealth Police officers visited Queensland Police headquarters and passed the information received to a detective sergeant of the Crime Intelligence Unit. On the day after the fire bombing the Commonwealth Police Commissioner wrote to his Queensland counterpart providing certain internal Commonwealth Police documents relating to the information which had earlier been passed orally to the Queensland Police. It is not known which members of the Queensland Police Force had access to the information once it was passed to that organisation.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HARRIS-DAISHOWA (AUSTRALIA) PTY LTD: DONATION TO AUSTRALIAN LABOR PARTY

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. In the light of Mr Unsworth today authorising his own television advertisement entitled `On the Right Track' and withdrawing the usual authorisation of Stephen Loosley, and today being the day on which the Australian Federal Police (AFP) is to hand its report on the Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd-Young-Loosley affair to the Director of Public Prosecutions, I ask: First, was Mr Unsworth privy to the contents of the Federal Police report; and secondly, will the Minister act, despite his earlier answer, to move to ensure that that report is made public either immediately or at least before the election, as called for today by the shadow Minister for Home Affairs, Senator Short, and the shadow Attorney-General, Mr Reith?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —To my knowledge there is no foundation whatsoever for the scurrilous suggestion that has been made in the question that Mr Unsworth, the Premier of New South Wales, has been provided with a confidential Australian Federal Police report. As I say, the report has certainly not come to me, nor to Senator Robert Ray, the Minister with responsibility for the Australian Electoral Commission. On my understanding it will be provided to the Director of Public Prosecutions-the honourable senator says today, but I do not know whether it will be today. However, I have seen some Press speculation to that effect. The fact is that the suggestion, may I also comment, carries an implication that perhaps somebody in the Australian Federal Police may have leaked the report to Premier Unsworth for some reason or another, and I totally reject that suggestion.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have already answered, in relation to the further question of the tabling of the report, the provision of the report to the Director of Public Prosecutions puts Mr Ian Temby in the position of making an assessment as to whether a prosecution should or should not go ahead. Mr Temby's office is safeguarded against political interference, and I am sure that this chamber would wish that position to be absolutely maintained. In that situation, the decision of the Director of Public Prosecutions whether to publish reasons, should he decide not to prosecute, is one for him alone. He may choose to do so. It is within his quite uninfluenced discretion so to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. In the light of Senator Tate's answer, will he indicate to the Senate whether he expects Mr Temby to make that decision in the interests of alleviating suspicion as to political pressure before the State election is called?
—I refuse to make any such request of Mr Temby. I have absolute confidence in his integrity and ability in dealing with these matters.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Finance, either in that capacity or in his capacity as Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to certain information that the Minister has released this week relating to fiscal imbalances which have been identified by the Queensland Government in its Budget sector and that Government's efforts to rectify those imbalances. Given the implications for the national economy of continued large deficits and excessive borrowing requirements by the States, can the Minister provide any information as to the indications of whether Queensland's efforts to rectify those imbalances will be successful? What indications are there that Queensland's own pace of adjustment will be as swift as is required to contribute effectively to adjustment in the national economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have here another attachment to the Queensland Cabinet submission to which I referred earlier this week. The Senate will remember that the submission itself was only about 1 1/2 pages. I said I understood that it was necessary to keep such submissions very short because Queensland Cabinet Ministers cannot read without moving their lips and therefore can read only to themselves. I have been assured by a member of the Queensland Parliament that that is literally true.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Is it in order for the Minister to read from stolen goods from the Queensland Cabinet, and to base an answer on them?
—There is no point of order.

—I must remember to keep my eye on Senator Boswell to see whether he has that particular attribute of Queensland Cabinet Ministers. This attachment lists a number of topics which it is suggested could be subjected to either greater efficiency or expenditure reductions-savings in one way or another. The items which have been brought forward to the top of the list survey where there seems to be a great deal of duplication between State Government departments, such as in the areas of valuation, which is currently done principally for local governments-if that function were cut out it would have to be picked up by local government-and government printing.

ANSWER.PARA: The submission indicates clearly that there is considerable confusion in the mind of the Queensland Under-Treasurer. He does not seem to understand that a government printer who retains his captive market-that is, government departments-cannot be regarded as a commercial printer. Sir Leo Heilscher seems to think that the principle of commercialism and retention of the captive market are quite compatible. That would suggest that the thought processes of National Party Ministers have rubbed off on him as well and that double-speak is as common in the Queensland bureaucracy as it is in the Queensland Government. The attachment mentions a few other trivial things such as the Government garage and convenience food facilities.

It is unlikely, to say the least, that the list in total will go anywhere near to addressing the prospective deficits of $160m to $215m over the next couple of years that the submission identified. The inevitable conclusion, therefore, is that there will be a very substantial increase in Queensland Government taxes over the next couple of years-that is, unless Senator Stone cares to address himself to the problems and tell the Queensland Government how to sort them out.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in my gallery of a former distinguished senator, Neville Bonner. On behalf of all senators, I wish him well on this visit to Canberra.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations to Mr Willis's statement in the House of Representatives last Wednesday when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: It remains our policy to try to bring the rate of growth in wages and the unit labour costs in Australia as close to our trading partners' as we possibly can.

I would add that I agree with that as a policy objective. I ask the Minister: Given Australia's poor overall productivity performance and the fact that our nominal unit labour costs are growing at more than twice the rate of the average of our major Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development trading partners, can he outline the consequences to Australia of a 6 per cent guaranteed minimum wage increase, which would be the result if the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) achieved its goal of increases based on the prospective inflation rate? What would be the impact on our international competitiveness?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a question which can only be described as hypothetical in every possible ramification. The fact of the matter is that the effect on productivity of any wage increase depends very much on what the trade-offs are, and that has yet to be determined. Government wages policy has changed over the last five years, but on each occasion when a change was foreshadowed the Opposition prophesied great gloom. That has not eventuated.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact of the matter is that there has been a significant reduction in real unit labour costs in this country such as has not been seen in the political life of the country before this Government was elected. I just have to remind honourable senators that real wages increased in 1982-83 by 15 per cent. That occurred under the residue of the former Government which is still here in opposition, with the addition of Senator Stone, who no doubt advised that Government on these matters at the time. We have the collection on the other side left. The comparison is very instructive and important.

In terms of what is happening in respect of the new wage system to be negotiated, the question of trade-offs in respect of productivity will be immensely important. If Senator Chaney seeks to make the point that we do not compare with the best possible examples overseas, I concede that. That is true and, as Mr Willis said, we have to take that into account.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I realise that in a supplementary question I cannot canvass the many comments which could be challenged in the Minister's answer, but I remind the Minister that I asked the question based on a statement of his ministerial colleague Mr Willis, who said that it was his Government's policy-the Government of Senator Button, Mr Willis and the rest of them-`to try to bring the rate of growth in wages and unit labour costs as close to our trading partners' as we possibly can'. Is the Minister, in his answer, conceding that the sorts of wage rises which would follow if we applied the principles expressed by the ACTU yesterday could only be justified if there were trade-offs which ensured that there were productivity increases which would absorb the wage level increases sought?

—If Senator Chaney does not realise it, he is one of the few who do not. What was said yesterday by the ACTU was a basic approach to its negotiating position relating to wages. What Mr Willis said in the Parliament last week was an indication of the concern which the Government will address in its negotiating position in relation to wages.
—Be frank about it.

—What does Senator Chaney mean when he says, `Be frank about it.'? What is he talking about? The fact is that those are the two positions. Those negotiations have to take place. I will not prejudice the outcome of those negotiations by adding any more to that point. Those are the two positions which the relevant parties have adopted.
—They are widely different positions.

—Senator Chaney can interpret them in that way if he wishes. It is very difficult-if I might use a popular phrase-to rush to judgment about that issue at this stage. We will await the outcome of the negotiations and no doubt we will be asked more questions when they are completed.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Home Affairs. I note that he was one of the few media commentators who, early in the evening of the last Federal election, was correct in predicting the final results. At what time on the night of the recent Adelaide by-election did the Australian Electoral Commission have a reasonable indication of the likely final result? What system of comparing current results with previous results is employed by the Electoral Commission in the preparation of advice to candidates and the public on election night? Has the Electoral Commission been examining methods of improving its methods of assessing likely results as the counting of votes progresses on the night?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the Adelaide by-election the Electoral Commission trialed a completely different method of collating the results. Normally, when booth figures are received they are tabulated in some way and put on the board. I must say that during the last election at times that method was not only slow but also in some cases misleading. On this occasion the Commission fed into the computer the progressive preferred vote from the 11 July election, fed in the figures for each booth and distributed preferences using about the same methodology that applied on 11 July. That meant that at one point on the night-at 7.41 p.m., in fact-a preferred vote swing figure of 8.94 per cent came up. That occurred about an hour and 40 minutes after the booths closed. It did not vary all night beyond about 0.3 per cent around that final preferred vote swing figure.

ANSWER.PARA: The task that now confronts us is whether, as we can always do that in a by-election, we can do a similar thing on a Federal election night which would involve 148 Federal electorates. That is something that we will work on with a view to getting a little more rational analysis of election results on the night. We are quite confident that it can be done. We will trial it during other by-elections, although I hope that we do not have to trial it during a full Senate election in New South Wales in the future. That might be just a little too difficult. I do not think, by the way, that any computer methodology or any other methodology could give us a clear idea of Senate results on the night. It is really best to wait for six or eight weeks and read about it in the paper.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SALE OF PUBLIC ENTERPRISES: CONSUMER IMPACT STATEMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer for Prices. In view of the opposition to privatisation expressed by the Government's advisory council on consumer affairs, the National Consumer Affairs Advisory Council, and the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations, will the Government take up the suggestion of the advisory council that, where the sale of a public enterprise is being considered, a consumer impact statement should be mandatory? Will the Minister ensure that such a consumer impact statement will investigate the questions of efficiency and pricing, particularly with regard to whether private enterprise would be necessarily any more efficient or any less costly; state clearly what the Government would do to maintain services to minority groups; and demonstrate how it would help consumers if cross-subsidisation, as applies, for instance, to Telecom Australia users, were to be discontinued?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a couple of points I would like to make at the outset in answering this question. It is very pleasing for me to be asked a question by the Australian Democrats on the subject of consumer affairs. I have spent the last 10 days trying to find out from them who their official shadow spokesperson is. Today someone has actually stood up. The other point I would like to make is that it is very pleasing to note that the Democrats have taken a much more constructive attitude to this paper than the one taken by Senator Alston yesterday. After the matter was brought to my attention yesterday I spent some time last night going through the document.

ANSWER.PARA: The position that the Government has on this matter, and the one that Senator Haines has pinpointed very well, is that the debate is a current debate and the Government has welcomed comment from the full spectrum of society. In the context of this debate it is quite apparent that the views of consumers will be very closely considered by the Government. Obviously, the report presented by the National Consumer Affairs Advisory Council will be pivotal in the Government's deliberations. The points that Senator Haines raised come from paragraph 59 and the conclusion of the report of the Advisory Council. I am sure that in the next few months those reports will be at the forefront of discussions.

The point I want to make in closing is that we should keep this debate in context. As we have discovered in recent days, the Government is responsive to the interests, attitudes and needs of consumers. In relation to the history of governments in this country, our attitude of responsiveness is totally different from the attitude shown by the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am delighted that the Minister actually got around to reading the report last night, since it is an integral part of his portfolio. I did not ask him whether he was going to consider or take anything on board; I asked whether the Government will actually do something about consumers' needs and opinions in future.

—I think it is quite apparent to Senator Haines, amongst others, that the whole question of privatisation has not been debated. Since the supplementary question was asked on a hypothetical basis I will not proceed to answer it.

—Is the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware that the South African Government has introduced sweeping restrictions on 17 opposition organisations, including the major political group, the United Democratic Front, as well as several human rights groups? These restrictions also apply to the black trade union movement. What is the Australian Government's position on these worrying developments? Will the Government make clear to the South African authorities the abhorrence with which Australians view such acts of political oppression?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government condemns in the strongest possible terms-I expect this position to be shared on a bipartisan basis across the entire Parliament-the imposition of draconian restrictions on 17 opposition political groups in South Africa including the major anti-apartheid umbrella group, the United Democratic Front. We also condemn in the strongest possible terms the very serious constraints on the elementary political rights of major black trade unions which have been imposed. The restrictions effectively prohibit political activities by opposition groups that do not operate within the apartheid system. They also attempt to limit the work of human rights organisations which have seriously embarrassed the Pretoria authorities through revelations of continuing widespread imprisonment without trial, mistreatment of detainees and the detention and ill-treatment of children.

ANSWER.PARA: Over recent months the South African authorities have tried, by severe security measures and Press censorship, to conceal from the outside world the scope and effectiveness of political opposition to apartheid. These new measures reveal that effective opposition has continued even in the face of such heavy-handed repression. The Australian Government believes that only by ending apartheid can confrontation and the risk of spiralling violence and suffering be avoided in South Africa. This in turn can only be achieved through genuine dialogue and the emergence of a spirit of reconciliation across the entire political spectrum. These new restrictions show that the South African authorities are prepared for political change only on their own terms. They are moving, tragically, even further away from reconciliation and they risk increasing the violence that they are allegedly designed to curb. One could only agree with the very dramatic expression of the concern of opposition groups in South Africa, as reported in the last day or so, that the lights are going out in South Africa as a result of these developments.

The United States has already expressed concern over these developments. In relation to our expression of concern, I have directed, in my capacity as Acting Foreign Minister, that immediate steps be taken to register Australia's grave concern with the South African Government through the Australian Ambassador in South Africa. I have also instructed the acting head of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to call in the South African Ambassador later this afternoon to make known in appropriate terms the views of the Australian Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Transport and Communications to his answer on Monday to Senator Messner's question concerning the internal Telecom Australia note circulated by Mr Guthrie which stated that the restructuring of Telecom had been postponed until after the New South Wales State election. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Acting Attorney-General. I draw the Minister's attention to section 130 of the Health Insurance Act, which states:

QUESTION.PARA: A person shall not, directly or indirectly, except in performance of his duties . . . make a record of, or divulge or communicate to any person, any information with respect to the affairs of another person . . .

What is the purpose of having this secrecy provision? In the opinion of the Solicitor-General, Dr Gavan Griffith, QC, the Minister administering the Act is not responsible for the release through his office of such confidential information. If the Minister is not responsible for the secrecy provisions, who is?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to add to the legal opinion that has been provided by the Solicitor-General, who is the most eminent practitioner--
—That is not what she asked you.

—I have been asked to comment on the Solicitor-General's interpretation of section 130 in so far as it relates to a Minister's responsibility. In the event of that question being asked, as I understand it, the honourable senator trying to elucidate my understanding of the relationship of section 130 to ministerial responsibility and in the course of the question disputing the Solicitor-General's understanding of that relationship, I have no comment to make.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I will repeat the question: If the Minister is not responsible for the secrecy provision-and the secrecy provision is there-who is responsible? That is the question I was asking.

—The statutes of the Parliament must be observed by all. The function of the Australian Federal Police and the Director of Public Prosecutions is to ensure that, if there has been no adherence to those provisions, the person or persons concerned in breaching them are brought before a court. The responsibility in relation to that particular statute-if its overall structure and requirements rest with anyone-rests with the Parliament which has made that particular statute. The fact is that the responsibility to adhere to the provision rests on all those who may be required to adhere to it. It is as simple as that.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Minister for Justice that on 22 February, in answer to a question asked by Senator Hill about the allegations made by a former National Crime Authority (NCA) Commissioner, Mr Max Bingham, that the work of the National Crime Authority in Queensland had been white-anted and that an undercover squad had to be withdrawn, he said:

QUESTION.PARA: It is not my policy to discuss the operations of the National Crime Authority publicly.

Can the Minister advise why the Government's policy of not discussing publicly operations and investigations was not adhered to by the Prime Minister this week when he admitted that his friend, Sir Peter Abeles, was under investigation by the National Crime Authority and ventured his opinion as to Sir Peter's innocence of wrongdoing? Is it not correct that the real reason that the Minister refuses to confirm the serious allegations made by Mr Max Bingham is that Mr Bingham's allegations are only too embarrassingly true? When will the Minister follow the Prime Minister's example and answer publicly legitimate concerns about the operations of the National Crime Authority? Will the Minister at last admit that the tightening up of procedures in the liaison contact role is insufficient to prevent the corruption in State police forces from compromising the operations of the National Crime Authority?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I may not have got down a note of all of the elements of Senator Newman's question. The honourable senator asked a question based on the so-called revelations of Mr Max Bingham, purportedly drawn on some knowledge he obtained as a member of the National Crime Authority. In so far as that was part of the framework of the question, my reply, which does not satisfy Senator Newman, was:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . it is not my policy to discuss the operations of the National Crime Authority publicly. From the outset I have been kept fully briefed by the Chairman of the Authority on developments in the matter and I do not believe that the public interest will be best served in this instance by further public comment.

That is the answer I gave Senator Newman last week. It is the answer to which I returned and gave Senator Hill also. Those words were supplied to me by Mr Justice Stewart before Senator Newman asked her question last week, as I think I explained to the chamber previously. It is for that reason that I adopted that particular set of words; I believe they are the words which best convey the need for me as the Minister with responsibility for the National Crime Authority to maintain the confidentiality of briefings I receive about the operations of the Authority.

In so far as reference was then made by the honourable senator to the Prime Minister, I have not seen the portion of the Hansard record to which Senator Newman referred. Therefore, I cannot comment on whether the Prime Minister commented in any way on an NCA operation. When I took to the Inter-Governmental Committee last November, I think it was, the proposals for the tightening of the procedures leading to the appointment of liaison officers between the State police forces, the Northern Territory police force, the Australian Federal Police and the National Crime Authority-proposals which Senator Newman had characterised as trivial and as not of any great consequence-they were perceived by the ministerial members of that Inter-Governmental Committee, who were not by any means merely members of Australian Labor Party governments throughout Australia, as going a long way towards ensuring the integrity of the operations of the National Crime Authority undertaken in a way which required liaison with those other police forces in the various jurisdictions around Australia.

It is clear that that is not the only step that ought to be taken, but it was a very significant step. It was thought by those Ministers, by the police commissioners and by the National Crime Authority itself to be a very good, proper and effective proposal which, you may recall, Mr President, enabled the National Crime Authority to enter into negotiations with a State before the liaison officer was appointed so that in fact the National Crime Authority would have an effective veto over the appointment of a person who might be nominated. It provided that the nominee ought to be a particular person rather than merely a holder of high office within the police force concerned. Those proposals were accepted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister whether the measures which he has outlined again today and which he has outlined in the past are sufficient. I am glad to note that he recognises that there may be more to do, but I have always asked him to outline the further steps he proposes to take. I further ask: Was the Prime Minister not aware of this policy? Has the Minister brought the Prime Minister into line?

—I have no intention of speaking to the Prime Minister about this matter. As to the general question of the protection of the integrity of the National Crime Authority from the possibility of compromise in carrying out its operations and protecting its witnesses, which I know is of great concern to this chamber-that matter was manifest in several questions asked last year, particularly by Senator Robert Hill-the fact is that the National Crime Authority undertakes its own procedures with a certain degree of meticulousness. I think that reflects very much the character of the Chairman of the National Crime Authority, Mr Justice Stewart, who is painstaking in his attention to the need to ensure that the National Crime Authority operates in such a way that it cannot be disrupted or in any way infiltrated by corrupt elements. I cannot go into the methods which are employed by Mr Justice Stewart and the members of the Authority to achieve that objective; nor, indeed, have I been--
—You have already got the problems. You will not admit to them. What are you going to do about them?

—I am saying that Mr Justice Stewart and the members of the Authority are currently employing a whole range of methodologies-they have employed them in the past and will do so in the future-which are designed to achieve the protection which the honourable senator quite rightly seeks. Given the experience that has now been built up after several years of operation, no doubt those particular protective devices are being continually refined.
—They have been, and we know they have failed.

—I say that they are being continually refined. The National Crime Authority has achieved such success and has obviously protected its operations to such an extent that this Parliament will be called upon shortly to extend its term of life. The Government intends to introduce legislation to repeal the sunset clause which presently will bring the National Crime Authority to an end on 30 June 1989. That legislation fulfils an election promise of the Prime Minister and, indeed, is supported by the Opposition. We believe that the National Crime Authority has had a tremendous impact in curtailing and disrupting organised crime in Australia. We look forward to the Parliament's support for the continuation of its very effective efforts.

—Can the Minister for Consumer Affairs inform the Senate as to what action the Government is taking to prevent consumers being charged excessive interest rates, which in some instances have reached almost 200 per cent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Childs raises a question that is of great concern to the Government, particularly in view of the excessive rates charged by some, albeit a very small number of loan sharks, but also because of the alarming proportions that consumer debt has reached in this country, the most recent estimates from the Reserve Bank of Australia estimating its level at $23 billion.

ANSWER.PARA: The primary responsibility for the regulation of the provision of credit rates rests with the States, but despite this a number of initiatives have been taken by government, both at State and Federal level, to address the problems involved. One avenue of recourse has been through a co-operative approach by States in the production of uniform credit legislation. This has been developed through the standing committee of consumer affairs Ministers. Legislation has provided, amongst other things, the ensuring of adequate precontractual disclosure of information about the effective rates of interest, prohibiting penalty clauses, and requiring credit providers to be licensed. As well, there are other provisions in the law which allow for contracts to be reopened because of unconscionability. There are also provisions in the Trade Practices Act which indirectly provide relief to consumers, prohibiting corporations from engaging in false or misleading or unconscionable conduct.

However, there are two initiatives on the immediate agenda which the Government hopes will both have an effect in terms of redressing some of the problems directly as well as having an educative effect on the community. In early April the Government will be hosting a national forum on consumer credit. This forum will bring together a whole range of representatives, including industry representatives from the banking and financial sectors together with trade unions and consumer groups. That forum will be the upcoming focal point of the Federal Government's activity in terms of education and co-operation with the sectors involved in consumer debt. As I said, though, the main responsibility rests with the States. Here I wish to mention the activities particularly in New South Wales where the State Minister for Consumer Affairs, Deirdre Grusovin, has taken a lead.
Opposition senators-Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously from the response I am receiving, Opposition senators do not seem to be concerned about constructive matters that are of concern to the citizens of New South Wales. Opposition senators can come in here with fabricated questions and delve in the gutter, but this is a basic issue that is of concern to the people of New South Wales. Those opposite would best serve their colleagues in New South Wales by listening quietly to the answer. As I said, Deidre Grusovin, the New South Wales Minister for Consumer Affairs, has taken the lead. Earlier this month she announced that the Commercial Tribunal in New South Wales was holding an inquiry into interest rates. This inquiry is due to report in mid-March and is already embarking on taking evidence from industry and consumer representatives.

ANSWER.PARA: The question raised by Senator Childs was specifically related to loan sharks. We at Federal level are pleased that Minister Grusovin has responded very quickly to a couple of instances involving loan sharks in New South Wales. One moneylender, a firm called Walter Pugh Pty Ltd, was forced to reduce its interest rates from a startling 144.4 per cent to a more reasonable 29 per cent, all because of the activities of the Tribunal. Another company, Nartic Finance Co. in Newcastle, had been charging 170 per cent but its licence was cancelled by the Tribunal.

The basic point that one should remember in looking at the activities of loan sharks is that in many instances people who have undertaken debts with such companies could have been eligible for loans from other appropriate organisations and could have paid interest rates much lower than those that have been charged. This particular instance highlights the major difference between the sort of approach that the Unsworth Government in New South Wales is taking in the interests of consumers. One can compare that to the hollow, empty policies in this area of an alternative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Acting Attorney-General, and it follows a question asked earlier by Senator Lewis in respect of the opinion provided yesterday by the Solicitor-General on the Blewett affair. I ask: First, did the Minister discuss the matter with the Prime Minister before seeking the opinion from the Attorney-General? Secondly, will he guarantee to the Senate that the Australian Federal Police investigation into the matter will not in any way be inhibited in its ascertaining of the facts, including Dr Blewett's involvement as a result of the Solicitor's opinion given in response to the extraordinary oral and narrow request by the Minister? Thirdly, will he also guarantee that when the Australian Federal Police investigations are completed the facts emerging from that investigation will be conveyed to the Solicitor-General with the request that he provide another opinion which takes into account these facts?

—Yes, I did hold discussions with the Prime Minister about the matters arising out of Dr Blewett's statement to the House of Representatives. Secondly, I can give an absolutely categorical and unequivocal guarantee that the Australian Federal Police will not be inhibited in the conduct of the investigation into these matters.
—How do you know that?

—In the sense that it is being implied that some sort of undue interference or pressure would be brought to bear to inhibit them in their investigations. As to the third element, no, I will not give a guarantee that that will be the case. The police investigation will be handed to the Director of Public Prosecutions; he will then use that police report to make his decision as to whether the prosecution should go ahead or not.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the answer to the third part of the question, I ask the Minister: Does that not make an absolute and complete mockery of the opinion received yesterday from the Solicitor-General?
—No, I do not believe it does.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. The Northern Territory, which again was excluded from Senator Baume's carefully chosen definition of mainland States, has an almost seven percentage points lower retention rate than New South Wales. In both cases that is greater than the difference between the average in the five mainland States and the New South Wales rate.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF ARTS, HERITAGE AND ENVIRONMENT

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 December 1987, on motion by Senator Puplick:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I want to use this opportunity to speak about how the actions of the Government in deciding to give the North Queensland rainforest World Heritage listing are affecting the lives of so many people in the northern parts of our State of Queensland. What puzzles me is why, when four-fifths of North Queensland tropical rainforests are never to be logged, it is necessary to put the North Queensland tropical rainforests on the World Heritage List at all. The reason why four-fifths are never to be logged is because they are in national parks and sections of timber reserves in State forests which are not available for logging because Queensland has one of the best forest management programs in the world.

Last year I visited the north Queensland rainforests. I was taken to an area outside Ravenshoe which had been logged two or three times. It was impossible to see where trees had been felled. By opening up the rainforest to the light the growth of the lovely trees there is encouraged. The area around the Crater National Park, habitat of the rare green possum, has been logged three times, the last time as recently as about 15 years ago. Thousands of tourists who visit this area would think that it was virgin rainforest.

I was interested to read in the Courier-Mail some time ago of the first independent study of the effects of World Heritage listing of north Queensland rainforest, compiled by professor of economics at James Cook University, Professor Percy Harris. He maintained that the Federal Government was either misleading Australia about the impact of logging on north Queensland rainforests or it intended to mislead the World Heritage Commission about the rainforests' quality. He said that the Government has claimed that the logging will destroy the integrity and heritage listing qualities of the rainforest but that it also claims that after 100 years of logging, sometimes uncontrolled, the integrity of these forests is still maintained. So both of those claims cannot be true; one of them must be invalid.

Of course, I could go on to deal with the number of jobs that will be lost as a direct result of the listing. Professor Harris maintains that about 1,994 jobs will eventually be lost, yet the proposal by the Government would create only 640 jobs in return. Professor Harris went on to say that the sudden cessation of rainforest harvesting will cause immediate and severe regional distress that can be avoided with a more balanced approach. But the Government does not seem to worry about the unemployment which will be caused in the area or the social effects that it certainly is having and will have on the people there. The Government should realise that small towns living off local industries can die. This is the real tragedy for north Queensland and, I would say, for Australia.

Senator Richardson is on record as saying that we can afford to save the rainforests, but he does not specify whose rainforests. Australia imports about 10 times more rainforest timber than is produced in north Queensland and I believe it is rather hypocritical to worry about saving our rainforest and yet continue to exploit the rainforests of the Third World. We should consider such factors in relation to the report of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. It seems wrong to me to worry about cutting down only Australian rainforests and not those in other lands. World Heritage listing was a political proposal. There is no doubt about that. Of course, the industry was in a State that has a non-Labor Government. As a senator for Queensland I have been very concerned about the Government's attitude and that is why I have raised this matter in relation to the report before us today.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am in continuation on this report. SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Minister that all his agencies of government, in fact all agencies of government, have a responsibility to disclose in their annual reports their objectives, their standards, the costs they incur and, if they have any revenue, the revenue they receive, and-this is the important point-the degree to which they have attained the objectives they have been set. This information is missing. I ask why. I would like the Minister's response at the conclusion of my address.

In the absence of such detail, many annual reports of government instrumentalities are becoming little more than vehicles for Government propaganda. While some information on expenditure has been provided in the report on hand, it is generalised and simply does not provide adequate detail for the layman, the person apart from those who have intimate knowledge of this subject, to make an assessment of the Authority's cost-effectiveness. Perhaps the Minister can provide us with some ancillary information that could be appended to that report. I remind the Minister-I thank him for his enthusiasm, marked by his note taking-that businesses in the private sector are increasingly called upon to be more accountable to their shareholders. I believe the same principle should apply in that the Automotive Authority should be responsible through the Minister to this Parliament. —What is new indeed. When we look at the record of the unions in Port Kembla it is a perpetual record of industrial disruption which appears to be aimed at destroying this industry.
