I said when we debated this last year that it is nonsensical to pretend that this is simply the result of some sort of problem with the management of BHP when we know that the great bulk of last year's disputation related directly to a dispute between the unions and the New South Wales Government. This latest one relates to one man-he is a $4m to $5m a day man. That is probably the market value of the steel that is not being sold because the raw iron that is being made is being dumped.

SPEECH.PARA: BHP is expected to stand down 1,000 workers at its Port Kembla steelworks, according to a report in this morning's media. The report states that more than 400 employees have been told to go home until further notice and the rest will be told of their fate next week. From the period Monday to Wednesday, BHP dumped more than 20,000 tonnes of molten metal. The Port Kembla steelworks is Australia's biggest. It produces about two-thirds of Australia's steel. The intriguing thing is that this strike is taking place not only in defiance of the New South Wales Industrial Commission, not only in defiance of the recommendation from the union leadership, but also in defiance of the deal made between the Government, the unions and management under Senator Button's famous steel industry plan which was going to save the world. It was going to save the industry and save Wollongong.

TALK.START.PARA: —We're further behind now in relative productivity internationally than when we started.

—That is exactly so. That is the point I made at the beginning of this speech, that we are in an even worse position in relation to the international steel industry than we were before Senator Button's magnificent plan was introduced. It has been a failure; he has been a failure. That failure is underlined by the destructive effect of the industrial relations chaos that is caused in that industry by the incompetence and/or meddling of the New South Wales Labor Government.
—What does he do? He introduces a Bill for a footwear, textile and clothing development authority.

—I shall refer to that matter in a minute. Having just established with awful clarity how this kind of deal, which depends on the decency and goodwill of the union movement, was doomed from the start, we now face the situation where the Labor Government will do the same sort of thing to another industry. It will not impose sanctions of any kind on that section of the tripartite deal-the unions-over which it is too gutless to impose any sort of control.
—It's their master.

—As Senator Parer says, once again the union movement demonstrates its role as the master of its political juniors, its political subservients, in this place. The reality is that this steel industry plan had no prospect of success while there were no sanctions against failure to meet obligations. We can ask the Government whether it really thought that the special relationship it had with the unions, which it talked about and which it trumpeted in the election campaign during which it continually misled the Australian people, would get the unions to abide by the terms of this agreement and that nothing else was needed.
—Abiding by the terms of the agreement? They don't know the meaning of the term.

—Unfortunately, history has demonstrated that to be so. The present situation-I think we should ask ourselves about this-is that the Government has committed large amounts of taxpayers' money, just as the company has committed its money, yet the other part of the deal is not being delivered. It seems to me that if ever a government gave consideration to going into this sort of deal-I will not say whether it is necessarily good or necessarily bad-with the Australian union movement, as evidenced by the south coast branch of the Federated Ironworkers Association (FIA), there would be a clear requirement, I believe, to enter into a contractual agreement, the breach of which would involve the imposition of penalties.

SPEECH.PARA: A disastrous penalty has been imposed upon the company with its $1.3m worth of investment. A disastrous penalty has been imposed upon Australia's balance of payments and on Australia's unemployment bill as people lose their jobs because of this union intransigence; but because of this Government there is no capacity to require the imposition of some form of penalty for the deliberate breach of orders to return to work legally established in accordance with a plan under which the Government has extracted from the unions an obligation that they clearly are not prepared to abide by.

I must say that I am very concerned at this kind of unwillingness by the union movement to meet what was a very reasonable requirement of Commissioner McMahon in the Industrial Commission. It strikes me as being deliberately aimed at some agenda that I simply cannot understand, unless it is an agenda involving the destruction of the steel industry, the destruction of jobs and the destruction of the economy in the Illawarra region. It is not as though the unions in that area have not been warned; they have been warned for years. The Minister himself has warned them. Last year Mr Keating went to Port Kembla and strongly criticised-with words and not deeds, of course-the unions which were destroying the steel industry at that time; but all to no avail. But what a reasonable proposition it was that Commissioner McMahon recommended. He said that the men should return to work and seek a negotiated settlement. They are disgusting words, are they not? Fancy suggesting that they seek a negotiated settlement! The unions responded appropriately. They said, `We will not tolerate that kind of foul language'. The only word they know is `strike'. A negotiated settlement, indeed! That would be a change of face at Port Kembla.

TALK.START.PARA: —And killing the jobs of their mates.
—Killing the jobs of their mates, as Senator Parer interjects. The members decided not to do that. Commissioner McMahon then ordered the workers--
—With respect, Senator, they didn't do anything of the kind. A few trade unions bosses decided that.
—I regret to say that there was a meeting of the strikers.
—What proportion of them was there?
—According to the newspaper report:

SPEECH.PARA: The 250 members met this morning to consider the recommendation . . .
That is 250 out of several thousand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I suggest to Senator Stone that Senator Baume can make his speech without any assistance.
—Out of many thousands of workers, 250 turned up, as Senator Stone quite rightly says. The newspaper articles continues:

SPEECH.PARA: But after discussion unanimously reaffirmed their previous position and have decided to stay out indefinitely.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was it the usual thing: `Shall we stay out and if any scabs are here, get them against the wall?'.

—The usual sort of industrial blackmail that takes place in Port Kembla was, I presume, exercised. The decent unionists, who are the great majority in Port Kembla, are forced into this situation and frankly, out of fear in many instances, will not turn up to such meetings and will not vote openly and publicly against such a strike call. They are having their jobs destroyed by the incredible behaviour of this small group of 250 members who turned up and who have their own agenda. When I say they have their own agenda, I mean it. There is a group in Wollongong, the Socialist Workers Party, to which many of these people belong, including some union organisers. That group has as its objective the destruction of the way of life that we have in Australia; and it is certainly determined to destroy `capitalism', whether or not that involves destroying jobs in the region.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say that there are far too many decent and honourable unionists in Port Kembla whose lives are now being disrupted and whose prospects of employment are being demolished by the agenda of a group of people who belong to a party which I believe has dishonourable objectives-whose objectives could not by any stretch of the imagination be regarded as being in the best interests of Australians but may well be in the best interests of a few politically oriented extreme leftists who, let us face it, are destroying this industry. We know that they are destroying this industry because the plan states that the industry will not survive and may not see out the twentieth century unless the level of labour disputation is reduced markedly, work practices are brought into line with those prevailing in other countries, and productivity is improved significantly.

Honourable senators will be interested to know that the quarterly report of the Steel Industry Authority, which came out a couple of Sundays ago and which contained so many grave warnings, was issued under the cover of a Press release from the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. That Press release made no mention whatever of any of those grave warnings in the report. It did not mention the fact that productivity in Australia had worsened in relation to other countries and that we would be even further behind the rest of the world than at the beginning of the steel industry plan. There was not one word about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that it was an honest oversight.
—I agree that it was an oversight. I cannot give it that adjectival description.
—We've had a lot of honest mistakes recently, too.

—This may be another of those `honest' mistakes which, as Senator Stone rightly points out, seem to have been happening non-stop. All we got in that covering Press release was a comment limited to the report's disclosure of a fall in industrial disputation in the September quarter. It is true that there was a fall in industrial disputation in that quarter to the lowest level since the steel industry plan. It followed the worst ever industrial record in the previous three months since the steel industry plan. One has to put them together to see what the average is. Now once again we are on the industrial disputation road at a cost of multimillions of dollars and at a risk to this industry and its future. The Press release totally ignored the grave warnings in the report.

SPEECH.PARA: In recent months Senator Button has continually sought to criticise those of us who for 18 months or so have been warning non-stop that the steel industry plan was falling apart and that the Government had to do something positive and effective to get the unions to play their part in this deal. It is clear from what Senator Button said in his criticisms of those of us who have made these warnings that he has no interest, no concern and no effective involvement in saving this industry. It has all got too hard. It is all the problem of the New South Wales Government or of the New South Wales Industrial Commission, or as a result of disputes relating to the New South Wales Government's workers compensation arrangements. None of it is Senator Button's problem. He keeps mouthing great hopes that things will improve. `I am very confident', he says, `that the new dispute settling agreements will resolve the problem'. I have news for Senator Button, wherever he is-and he is not present for this debate, a debate that is central to Australia's economic future in an area for which he is responsible. It is worth pointing out to Senator Button that he has failed because in the plan he did not provide any sanctions against deliberate, bloody-minded, destructive union activity aimed at destroying this industry.

Senator Button has said, `The Government does take a role through industrial relations policies of one kind or another'. If this is the role that he sees he has properly played, all I can say is that his industrial relations policies of one kind or another have not been good enough. We now face a series of continual disasters. The approach adopted by Senator Button in the past when either Senator Lewis or I have raised this matter has been condescending and is now seen to be clearly ridiculous. The industry-and these are not my words but those of the Steel Industry Authority-faces destruction. It may not last 12 years because that is when this century ends. I stress that the Minister in putting out his Press release covering a report that warns that the industry may not last 12 years did not even address himself to that warning. What kind of Minister is it who pretends that everything will be all right on the night?

Last time we questioned Senator Button about this matter he said, `The steel industry plan is alive'. He thought that it was a silly question of mine to ask him whether he believed that the company's regrettable decision which it had to make not to proceed with major structural improvements at Port Kembla No. 4 blast furnace because of continual labour disruption meant that his steel industry plan had failed. I now ask a question of Senator Button about the latest round of industrial unrest, about which apparently he can do nothing, about which he has said nothing, about which this Government has no desire to do anything because it is all the fault of New South Wales anyway. My question is: What will this Government do to save the steel industry? Does it have any desire to save the industry? Will it with any willingness give us any evidence to take strong and positive steps to save the steel industry and the jobs of tens of thousands of Australians that are now at risk?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Michael Baume has proposed a motion and has expressed concern that Senator Button is not in the chamber. All Senator Button will have to do is to go back to the Hansard record of 3 November when Senator Michael Baume then, as he has today, demonstrated his paranoia and his lack of understanding of industrial relations issues. On that occasion he moved a motion drawing attention to:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to bring to an end union sabotage of the steel industry plan.

He has given us the same one-sided rehash of the old arguments he used then, egged on by Senator Stone. The shareholders of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) are about to have an important meeting. If Senator Michael Baume wanted to give BHP shareholders a message about how they might improve the results of their company, it would be that BHP's management should start to try to change the attitudes to industrial relations it has had for a long time. I think that there has been some improvement in some of the industrial relations activity since the last debate on this matter in this place in November last year but we have to have a much more balanced analysis than Senator Michael Baume has given us. We cannot rely on just the abuse of trade unions. Interjections by Senator Parer about traitors are not the answer to the problem. I hope to deal with the various parts of the motion and show that there is an answer to what Senator Baume has proposed. When dealing with complex problems it is necessary to look at their history, and to ensure that they are carefully examined when we are trying to give mature consideration and not just relying on prejudice. At the very beginning the motion refers to:

the warning contained in the latest quarterly report of the Steel Industry Authority that the Australian steel industry `may not see out the 20th century' unless the level of management/labour disputation is reduced markedly, work practices are brought into line with those prevailing in other countries and productivity improved significantly . . .

When we consider that the Steel Industry Authority report that Senator Baume quoted relates to the three months period to 30 September 1987, the warnings contained in the report must be seen in the appropriate timeframe. The industry had just emerged from a difficult first half of 1987, with industrial disputation reaching high levels for a number of reasons which we went through on 3 November. A significant part of those losses of production was caused by what are described as technical errors. In part they could be said to be management errors because of the lack of skill at one level, one could say, in introducing new equipment in the refurbishing plan at the steelworks. A significant factor was that contribution by technical errors.

In the September quarter there was a signi- ficant fall in the number of man-hours lost due to industrial disputes, and that trend has continued into 1988 with, of course, the exception of the dispute this week, with which I will deal very thoroughly. When honourable senators examine the totality of the position they will see that it is not as Senator Baume has said. What I am saying gives the lie to what Senator Baume referred to as `non-stop industrial unrest'. BHP and the unions have in fact moved towards industrial peace to the extent that they have had national negotiations which resulted in a national negotiating agreement, and the industrial problems of early last year should be seen as an aberration. I acknowledge what Senator Baume was saying regarding the superannuation dispute; it was an extraneous matter but one that did occur. These things do occur, and that has happened, but there has been an improvement.

I would just like to refer to some of the improvements that have occurred that have the possibility to bring far greater improvement in the steelworks particularly. I am referring at the moment to Port Kembla. BHP and the unions have gone into discussions on arrangements covering consultation procedures, work practices, productivity improvements, the extent and time of job shedding, and other industrial relations issues, with the aim of establishing an industrial agreement that will provide the basis for industrial harmony after this year. Of course, Senator Baume has not had one good word for that positive work that is taking place because, as usual, he is simply concentrating on the negative. The Steel Industry Authority is actively promoting this industrial agreement and has been very successful in generating significant progress on this front.

The other thing that Senator Baume has not mentioned a word about is the significant second-tier agreements in the steel industry; 62 separate agreements have been reached in the slab and plate products division alone. Hundreds of meetings have taken place-not a dispute-but Senator Baume, who lives off industrial disputes, does not mention that. He cannot see the positive negotiations that took place, which meant in most cases significant concessions being given on the trade union side-these terrible people that Senator Baume has just abused. These people did, with management, I think indicate in those second tier negotiations the possibility of improving industrial relations. Of course, these agreements should provide the basis for future plant level consultation and arrangements. What I am concerned about is that I do not think BHP management has been able to move far enough. I will deal with that. I have said it before, and I have based what I said on the experience of BHP management over many years and the fact that it has had one of the worst backgrounds, or worst reputations, in the total industry in Australia. Paragraph (b) of Senator Baume's proposed motion says:

`That the Authority is deeply concerned that the Australian steel industry may at the end of the Steel Industry Plan be further behind its overseas competitors than it was at the inception of the plan unless some rapid improvements can be made in the industry's performance'.

The steel industry plan warned in September that rapid improvements in the industry's performance would be needed if it was to make gains relative to its overseas competitors by the end of the plan. That is the end of this year. Since the inception of the plan BHP has become one of the world's lowest cost steel producers. As a result of its low cost raw materials, of the massive $1.3 billion that I acknowledge has been made available in the investment program, of improvements in work practices and of the resultant productivity gains which have been achieved, the Steel Industry Authority has rightly pointed out the need to build on those gains.

Now, I am putting all the factors. I am being fair about it. Something that Senator Baume pathologically cannot do is be fair about all the factors that have meant that BHP costs are low. I acknowledge, of course, the change in the value of the Australian dollar. But the steel industry, like the manufacturing sector generally, must continue to improve its competitiveness, and that is what this Government, and particularly Senator Button, have inspired Australian industry about and have constantly emphasised by particular plans. I see also that Senator Stone denigrates the textile and clothing industry. It is significant that that is another industry employing thousands of people who do not speak English as a first language, and Senator Stone--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: I claim to have been misrepresented and ask the honourable senator to withdraw that totally false allegation in which he claimed that I was denigrating the footwear, clothing and textile industries. I am quite prepared to criticise many aspects of the industry, but I did not say that. What I did was to criticise this Government for bringing into this place today a Bill to set up a Footwear, Clothing and Textile Development Authority. The honourable senator should get the facts right.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: Senator Stone jumped to his feet on a point of order and then claimed to have been misrepresented, which are two different things under the Standing Orders. I really think you should instruct him in future to go to his point of order if he claims to have been misrepresented. When the senator has finished speaking, Senator Stone can correct what he likes. It is the tradition to grant leave where necessary, and I understand that if one claims to have been misrepresented one does not even have to seek leave. It does interrupt the flow of debate unfairly. I am certain that on some occasions Senator Stone will be on his feet and will not want his flow of debate interrupted. It is a good tactic, but it is not within the Standing Orders.

—The Standing Orders require the citing of a particular relevant standing order in taking a point of order. That was not the case, Senator Stone. You are standing, and there is no point of order. There is an ability for you to make a statement in the way that is usual in the Senate at the conclusion of Senator Childs's speech or at the conclusion of the debate.

—I do not want to upset Senator Stone, and I certainly do not want to waste my time on him. If anything has offended him, I will withdraw it. What I was trying to talk about was the importance of the human capital that exists in this country. I was saying that in the steel industry it is common to employ many people whose language is not English, people who left school before the age of 15-the people predominant in the work force involved in the industrial dispute that Senator Baume was referring to. It is significant that the textile and clothing industry is one of the key industries for people with those backgrounds. When I criticise BHP I do so because I believe it has not given enough consideration to its human capital and to developing that capital. Too often it is using its might, its power, to crush people. I was saying that it was necessary to look at those things in order to have a balanced judgment.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to paragraph (c) of the motion. That is the reference to the industrial disputes and technical problems. I will not read it all because Senator Stone has taken some of my time, but it is there for honourable senators to see. While productivity levels in the Australian steel industry need to improve beyond what has already been achieved under the steel plan, the industry's position is significantly better than the bald productivity figures suggest. Published productivity figures measure output of raw steel per man, but take no account of saleable steel. BHP's investment in improved processes has increased the yield of saleable steel without increasing raw steel output. This is in accord with the point that Senator Button has emphasised so often: the importance of value added to Australian manufacturing. The Authority also takes no account of the degree of downstream processing which is value added to the raw steel. The product mix varies widely between competing steel companies, with BHP extensively engaged in value added processes. Comparisons with overseas producers are invidious as the statistical bases vary enormously. The common practice of excluding maintenance and other support staff, for example, can increase the figures for productivity levels at a stroke. I expect that unfortunately, the productivity figures for more recent periods will be down as a result of the unavoidable and technical problems that I have referred to; not because of industrial disputes.

I turn now to some of the problems, the problems that Senator Baume does not allude to. The people of Wollongong are facing a major problem in the steel industry at Port Kembla under a plan known as the mechanical maintenance plan. A multi-skilling program of immense proportions is taking place. The pressure is on for completely restructured awards and skills but in the process of this restructuring several thousand people will be laid off. Many others feel that this restructuring will lead to the simple deskilling of their work. Morale of the work force at Port Kembla is very low. Such factors should be considered if the Senate wants to have a sober analysis of the problem of the steel industry. Many workers feel frightened by the kinds of changes they are expected to make. As I said, these are people who are migrants, with poor English and inferior education and who have left school at a very early age. Many of the workers believe that these problems have been brought about by management's desire to move to a system in which there is a heavy reliance on contract labour. That is a further apprehension among people in the industry.

This Government, more than any other, has recognised the need for a flexible, highly skilled work force. Whilst we want to press for that we also understand that it can be brought about only with the co-operation of both management and labour, by building mutual confidence. Change must be brought about in a humane fashion and this will not be achieved unless the work force co-operates. Unfortunately, BHP has a very bad history and BHP management is notorious for being inflexible. The world is not moving in the direction of such an attitude and progressive companies now give greater attention to the training of their employees. This must be understood as the background to the outlandish statements that have been made by Senator Baume. I hope that the Government can become more involved in this area, using its good offices. I realise the background of this plan but sometimes the Government, in working out how best it can co-operate, is able to facilitate the solving of any difficulties people in a factory or group of factories are having.

I refer to the industrial dispute that Senator Baume has been raging about. What we are talking about here-and I do not have a perfect knowledge of it but I have spoken with an official of the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia-is a ladle that carries something like 200 tonnes of metal in it. A protective shield was bent or broken. I am not quite sure which but the area that was bent or broken was treated with Kowool, a fibreglass-type substance. The ladle was activated five or 10 minutes afterwards and the gate would not work. It was clear that the equipment was badly damaged. The workers made a decision that as the company had not adequately corrected the defect-they thought it was dangerous that the company had not fixed the problem-they would not handle the equipment for 48 hours. I assume that was to make sure that the company would effectively make the repairs. The company retaliated and brought the equipment into operation virtually immediately. In a time honoured tradition, because the people had made a decision, the first person who was asked to operate that equipment refused and that person was sacked, which is a classic way in which industrial disputes occur.

Senator Baume has made the implication that this person who was accidentally there-he happened to be a shop steward of the union-was a sinister person. The way I took what he said was that it was a one-man dispute. Senator Baume's description is a gross falsification of the incident I have described to honourable senators. It is a rough description showing that the workers had a real concern about safety. In a time honoured tradition the person who was asked to do it, the workers having made a decision, refused to handle the work. We have seen Senator Stone helping Senator Baume by talking about trade union bosses.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did not require any assistance from me.

—Yours was like a falsetto voice egging him on with your New Right philosophy of blaming union bosses for everything. What happened, of course, was a classic example. We see in the report in the Sydney Daily Telegraph today that the officials of this union, because they could see the advantage of referring the matter to the State Industrial Commission, recommended to the workers that they return to work so the dispute could be settled. The officials of the ironworkers union in Port Kembla recommended a return to work. But we do not yet have slaves in this country. For right or wrong reasons, the workers made the opposite decision. This happens all the time. Even senators are sometimes wrong. People disagree with their leaders. In this case, I believe the people were probably wrong because any union official would know that returning to work would allow the matter to be dealt with. But we are talking about workers who are worried. I have described the fear they have about rapid change being considered in their place of work. We are talking about people who come from just about every country one can nominate. They have a different native tongue and difficulties communicating and understanding the rather complex industrial structures that we have.

SPEECH.PARA: These are the reasons why we have an industrial dispute. It is not a dispute organised on high by officials of the union. It is a complete lie and a complete fallacy for the Opposition to say that this is some sinister plot by trade union officials. Anybody sombre and concerned about getting a result should remember the workers at the Ford motor plant at Broadmeadows where workers under great pressure-the pressure of a speeded up production line-finally revolted against their union officials and revolted against everybody because they found the position intolerable. There is an element present in this dispute of people being very worried about safety and therefore not doing what those people who might be wiser and more knowledgeable of how the industrial system can be properly used would do.

Nevertheless, they are acting in a democratic way and making decisions that they are entitled to make. If there were a better climate, if there were a 20-year history of good industrial relations, or if it involved another group of workers, perhaps they would trust management. Unfortunately, in this particular case we do not have that trust. I mention those things because I think it is important to get the other side. We all know that we get a very one-sided version of events from Senator Baume.

I would like to deal now with paragraph (d) of the motion. I will not go into its full detail. I have answered the question relating to industrial disputation, but I remind honourable senators that the 62 agreements negotiated in the second tier arrangements were an indication of an improvement in relationships. They indicate great flexibility as far as the work force is concerned. But, as with all industrial relations issues, one just does not have smooth sailing. So whilst there has been an improvement in the march of industrial relations, unfortunately we still have not been able to overcome these problems.

A proper analysis of the motion we have before us shows that although its wording is more balanced than Senator Baume's previous effort, his calling on the Hawke Government to rescue the collapsing steel industry is a typical overstatement. The situation has improved. We have an industrial dispute that has to be looked at and analysed separately. Every industrial dispute has a life of its own and must be examined carefully. We should not allow the prejudice of coalition senators to enter into what is a complex situation.

Above all, this Government, through its plans in a whole range of industries, has attempted to show its goodwill and its interest in the revitalisation of manufacturing industry, helping the parties in industry to come together. Unfortunately, the Opposition is pathologically incapable of trying to bring people together. Senator Baume, who has attacked the Unsworth Government, is a classic representative of the coalition parties. If they were to take power in New South Wales we could be absolutely certain that we would have complete disputation in the steel industry from day one of a Greiner government. Not only would we have Senator Baume and his protege, Mr Greiner, in New South Wales but also we would have Senator Stone's representative in New South Wales as the other 40 per cent of a coalition government. Anyone listening to this broadcast must realise that the problems of the steel industry are complex and difficult. There is no earthly chance of a coalition government in New South Wales ever assisting in their resolution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Michael Baume's motion and point out that it calls on the Hawke Government to rescue its collapsing steel industry plan by giving practical and effective support to the Steel Industry Authority's attempts to encourage `all parties to seek some common ground in the development of plant level agreements in an effort to secure the long term future of the Australian steel industry'. I totally reject and refute the last statements made by Senator Childs about the coalition parties not having any idea about bringing people together to solve disputes. We totally support proposals which would bring people together to resolve disputes. That is the only way it can be done. Senator Childs is quite wrong when he makes that suggestion. I also refute any suggestion that this is a bash on the union movement. It is also not a bash on Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP). It is a bash on this Government and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, for lack of action. It is also, in part, a bash on the Unsworth Government for the role that it has played in the problems at Port Kembla.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me go back to the question of the unionists. I do not have to criticise the unionists and their leaders in relation to this dispute. Senator Childs has already done that for me. Senator Childs has acknowledged that the workers in this dispute are wrong. That is the way he put it. He then tried to explain what excuses they might have for making the decision they have made. But he acknowledged that they are wrong. So, as I said, there is no need for me to be critical of the unionists and the employees down there. I understand that only 250 employees were present at yesterday's meeting at which they decided to continue the dispute, in other words, to stay out on strike. There are 12,000 employees at Port Kembla. Those people are putting at risk the entire industry. They are putting at risk their town, Wollongong, and the district. They are putting at risk opportunities and ideas which others might have for investment in the area because of the militant approach they have towards any issue which upsets them.

I go back to my criticism of the Unsworth Government. The massive industrial disputation which occurred in the area last year was brought about, not because of any dispute between the union and BHP but because of a dispute which the union had with the Unsworth Government over workers compensation matters. The union took out its spite against the Unsworth Government by striking, to the detriment of the company, the steel industry and its colleagues. I say to those unionists that they will get their opportunity next Saturday week to take out their spite against the Unsworth Government. The solution to their problem is to throw out the Unsworth Government and put in Nick Greiner.

In August 1983, this Government, a very short time after it came to office-a few months-announced its steel industry plan. Senator Button moved in and explained how the Australian Labor Party would solve the problems in the steel industry. The stated long term objectives of the plan were the creation of a long term, viable steel industry with job security for employees and production at internationally competitive prices. There were four parties to the plan and each made specific commitments. The Commonwealth Government, on behalf of the people of Australia-I remind the Senate that it is not the Commonwealth Government on its own behalf or even on behalf of the members of the House of Representatives and senators; it is the Commonwealth Government on behalf of the people of Australia-promised bounty assistance on four products to a ceiling of $71.6m per annum, with a guaranteed share of the market of 80 per cent.

It also promised a fast track anti-dumping system, an import warning system, quotas on reduced tariff imports from developing countries and the creation of the Steel Industry Authority. In the plan BHP undertook to continue the operation of the Port Kembla, Newcastle and Whyalla steel works, to provide job security for the period of the plan-provided that the plan was successful-to adopt an $800m investment plan over the first four years, which has been very substantially exceeded, and to keep prices in line with the consumer price index.

The unions' promises were effected by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) on behalf of the unions. The ACTU undertook to ensure that demands for wage increases would be in accordance with the prices and incomes accord and kept within community standards. It promised to re-establish an initial productivity level of 205 tonnes per employee per annum. Then the various State governments agreed to minimise the rises in State charges to the steel industry and to provide an improved industrial climate. One would have thought, with those four parties agreeing to those things, that this was going to be a successful plan. The problem was that the plan was flawed from the outset. It made no provision to commit employees, shop stewards and local branches of the various unions to the undertakings given on their behalf by their peak bodies. The ACTU had made commitments on behalf of the unions but ultimately it was unable to deliver or to accept responsibility. Even the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia, overall, was unable to deliver because it was unable to control the branches down on the shop floor. The shop stewards and the local branches were not prepared to accept commitments given on their behalf by their peak bodies.

There were no sanctions either on any of the parties for failure to fulfil their responsibilities. BHP has fulfilled its responsibilities, what it said it would do, so the sanctions there did not really matter. BHP is a company in which the decisions can be made at the top and delivered. So when it committed itself to this plan it was able to deliver. But the union movement is not constructed like a company. The power in the union movement rises from the floor; it does not come down from above. So the commitments made by the ACTU were unable to be delivered because there was no desire on the shop floor to deliver them and, in any event, there were no sanctions in the agreement. Therefore I say that the plan was flawed from the outset.

I add that the initial productivity target of 205 tonnes per employee per annum was too low and failed to recognise that the production per employee per annum involved constant catch-up. The rate of catch-up needed to be well beyond the trends in national productivity to become and remain internationally competitive.

I now turn to the New South Wales State Labor Government. It failed to involve the union movement in New South Wales in the introduction of work-care compensation, and this became a major issue in industrial disputation. The unions, as I have mentioned, reacted not against the State Government, which they could do next Saturday week, but against the company. As I said, if the unionists in this area wish to show their feelings towards the State Labor Government, they may do so next Saturday week by voting out the Unsworth Government, and that action will not place their jobs in jeopardy.

Let me also add unequivocally, so there is no confusion, that BHP's man-management techniques and communication with the work force were certainly not as good as they might have been, particularly over work force shedding and work practice changes. The steel plan makes provision for bounties to increase when production goes down, and this acts as a cushion against industrial unrest and low productivity. It is only recently that BHP has looked to becoming export oriented, and some criticism can be levelled at the management for its tardiness in seeking export markets. The Federal Government has failed to protect its investment in the plan and correct the flaws which allow the unions to abrogate their undertakings. As I have indicated, there is fault on both sides as far as BHP and the unions are concerned, but there is certainly also fault with both the New South Wales State Government and the Federal Government, which is not protecting the interests of the people of Australia.

The Western world's crude steel output jumped by 17.5 per cent in 1987. Japan, the biggest steelmaker, boosted output by 16.6 per cent in 1987. South Korea posted a 24 per cent increase, and Brazil an 8.3 per cent rise. Compare that with BHP's output of 285 tonnes per employee per annum for the September 1987 quarter. Its very best effort was in the quarter ending July 1985 with 304 tonnes per employee per annum. Compare that with the China Steel Corporation of Taiwan, which has moved from 428 tonnes per employee per annum in 1985 to 493 tonnes per employee per annum in 1986. Even the beleaguered US Steel was producing 579 tonnes per employee per annum in September 1987, a productivity level almost double that being achieved by BHP.
On page 2 of the latest Steel Industry Authority quarterly report for September 1987 are these two paragraphs:

The Authority is deeply concerned that the Australian steel industry may at the end of the Steel Industry Plan be further behind its overseas competitors than it was at the inception of the Plan unless some rapid improvements can be made in the industry's performance. The raw material cost advantage enjoyed by BHP cannot sustain the industry indefinitely in the face of major advances being achieved by overseas steel producers.

The Authority is of the view that unless the level of management-labour disputation is reduced markedly, work practices are brought into line with those prevailing in other countries and productivity improved significantly the Australian steel industry may not see out the twentieth century. On the other hand, the Authority believes that if these issues can be satisfactorily resolved, significant opportunities exist in overseas steel markets for BHP to expand capacity and to increase exports. There must be a clear commitment through productivity to the development of these overseas markets because continuity of supply of consistent tonnage is essential to achieve this end.

Despite that warning the unions at Port Kembla have again demonstrated their lack of understanding of how industrial action places their jobs in jeopardy. Their latest foolishness is frankly almost unbelievable. As Senator Childs has acknowledged, if they would only go back to work, perhaps the dispute could be resolved in accordance with established practices. An article in the Illawarra Mercury of the 24th of this month states:
Port Kembla slab cast workers twice rejected a return to work call yesterday and voted to stay out on strike, threatening further stand-downs at the plant.

BHP Steel Slab and Plate Products divisional general manager Jerry Ellis said the dispute, which has already led to Basic Oxygen Steelmaking workers being sent home, was ``very damaging and placing jobs at risk.''

Another part of the same newspaper refers to the case of Mr Alan Carr, `the slab caster delegate who was dismissed for refusing to work a ladle of molten steel because he claimed it was unsafe'. The decision to refuse to return to work `went against the recommendation of the State Industrial Commission's deputy president justice McMahon and the Federated Ironworkers branch secretary Nando Lelli, who supported the return to work'. Another meeting was held at 10 o'clock this morning, and I understand that the decision was to remain out on strike. It was very pleasing to read the following in the Sydney Morning Herald of the 23rd of this month:
BHP is planning a radical departure from its steel strategy of the past decade by boosting raw steel output and embarking on a major export drive.
Over the next three years, the Big Australian plans to spend $360 million on plant at Whyalla and Sydney that will enable it to boost exports by up to 50 per cent.

The additional equipment, a $200 million slab caster at Whyalla and Sydney's $160 million mini steel mill (which is already under construction), will enable BHP to export surplus output from its steelworks at New- castle and Westernport in Victoria.

Companies making commitments such as this spend very substantial sums of money. It is now up to the unions, to the State Government and to this Federal Government to demonstrate support for the plan by honouring their undertakings in order to make the industry internationally competitive. There is no reason why anyone should expect taxpayers to featherbed the steel industry. Certainly, there is no justification for renewal of this plan when neither the State Government nor the unions seem prepared to play ball. To provide more Federal taxpayers' money would be pouring more money down the drain unless the participants come to their senses. We would like to know what the Federal Government and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, are going to do about this. Does the Minister wash his hands of it and say that he has done all that he can do and will now remain silent and allow the parties in some way or other to resolve this dispute, when it has become quite clear that the union activities at Port Kembla are such that some other approach must be taken? The Opposition calls on the Hawke Government to rescue its collapsing steel industry plan.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The quarterly report of the Steel Industry Authority is yet another indictment which highlights the incompetence of the Hawke Labor Government-this time in regard to industry policy. That is why I strongly support the motion moved by Senator Michael Baume which, on the basis of shortcomings in the operation of the steel industry plan highlighted in the Authority's report, called on the Hawke Government to rescue its collapsing steel industry plan by giving practical and effective support to the Authority's attempts to encourage all parties to seek some common ground in the development of plant level agreements in an effort to secure the long term future of the Australian steel industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Three commitments were required to allow the steel industry to work-commitments by the company, the public and the unions. The company was to invest $800m, the public purse was to provide up to $71.6m a year in the form of bounties and the unions were to provide industrial peace. More specifically, the unions agreed that wage costs would be contained within prevailing community standards consistent with the prices and incomes accord; as an initial target to re-establish a productivity level of 250 tonnes per employee per annum, with future increases to be above the trend rate in national productivity; and to adhere strictly to established grievance settlement procedures.

If that is the Government's idea of industrial harmony, union co-operation and consensus, I would like to hear its definition of harmful disruption.

I would also be interested to hear its definition of the words `fair' and `summary'-particularly in the context of Press releases giving `fair summaries' of statutory reports. I refer, for example, to the one concerning the release of the quarterly report of the Steel Industry Authority by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button). It is yet another classic example of government by Press release. Dated Sunday, 14 February, it purports to summarise the Steel Industry Authority's report for the quarter. In self-congratulatory overtones the Minister announced, firstly, an improved performance for the quarter and then recorded his pleasure at reduced amounts of time lost through industrial disputes. He went on to express hopes that consultation and co-operation between BHP and the unions would lead to a bright future. There was not one word of the loud warning bells sounded by the Authority in its report. They, apparently, were not worth mentioning in the media release.

We all know that the reason for the temporary reduction in industrial disputation in the September quarter was the sweetheart deal between the unions and the Unsworth Labor Government to ensure industrial peace in the months leading up to the New South Wales State election. But the current strike at BHP shows that the sweetheart deal is disengaging, because it is now clear that the Unsworth Government is heading for defeat. The unions no longer see any benefit from their quiet acquiescence before the election and are going for broke.

Meanwhile, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is engaged in his own version of the Norman conquests, as Greg Norman's partner in the ESP Pro-Am Golf Tournament. I am told that on the very first tee he hooked his shot into a group of spectators and was heard to yell, `Two!'. Greg Norman asked him what that meant. The Prime Minister replied that it was a fore after he had finished taxing it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I saw the first hole on television. He didn't hook into the crowd. He duffed a shot on the second hole.

—It was on the second hole, was it, Minister? As if to emphasise problems in the industry, BHP is running television advertisements congratulating small business on using its products, while at the same time the Government is throwing more small businesses on the scrapheap. So the alarm in the Steel Industry Authority report is proving to be right on the button, but sadly ignored by Senator Button, the responsible Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: It is little wonder that BHP has had enough and wants to pull out of the plan in the hope that it can cut its losses a little before the plan expires naturally, in agony, at the end of the year. The only successful steel plan that this Government has under way at the moment is to steal people's superannuation. The Government, in this case, in the electorates and in industry, is proving as deaf as a post to even the loudest alarm.

The key to any industrial plan's success is productivity, which, in the case of the steel industry, fell dramatically from the end of 1985. In fact, it plunged over a 12-month period from 280 tonnes per man year to 240 tonnes per man year. This created, by the end of last year, a backlog of unfilled orders which have been carried forward as a result of production losses earlier in the year. Then there was some recovery. But amongst other unheard warnings raised in the Authority's annual report-that is, unheard by the Minister, according to his Press release-the increase in domestic despatches during the last quarter was, and I quote:

. . . largely achieved at the expense of export deliveries, which fell by 18 per cent. This practice of exporting only the surplus above the Australian requirement, while having some local benefit, does little for the development of long-term export markets.

In fact, BHP's exports for the first nine months of last year were down 34 per cent on 1985 figures. What-except briefly in the September quarter-was causing most concern to the Authority? Industrial disputes. Co-operation and consultation, the report adds, are desperately needed within the steel industry, in which productivity has failed to show any sustained improvement over the past two years. The following point is made: the poor productivity performance of the Australian steel industry is in stark contrast to the performance of overseas steel producers. Productivity levels in the United States were almost double that being achieved by BHP. Here is a warning really worth omitting from any self-congratulatory government handout:

The Authority is deeply concerned that the Australian steel industry may at the end of the steel industry plan, be further behind its overseas competitors than it was at the inception of the plan, unless some rapid improvements can be made in the industry's performance.

Unless the level of management-labour disputation is reduced markedly, work practices are brought into line with those prevailing in other countries and productivity improved significantly, the Australian steel industry may not see out the twentieth century. It seems that while the industry may not see out the twentieth century the unions are yet to enter the twentieth century with their outdated nineteenth century attitudes to industrial relations.

When we consider that today's export market is only 13 per cent of total steel production, compared with 30 per cent in the 1970s, the importance of the domestic market and stability in the workplace assume greater significance. In fact, industrial problems so exacerbated commissioning and operational problems that BHP was forced to import materials in the September quarter in order to meet domestic demand. However, of those previously mentioned points, none were important enough to be included in the Minister's Press release summary. Let us go back a little further to the Steel Industry Authority's annual report for 1986-87. Page 2 of that report states:
Preliminary net profit for the BHP Steel International Group for the year ended 31 May 1987 fell almost $54 million to $200 million . . .

This reduction in net profit was the direct result of a combination of operational difficulties leading to higher costs, an increase in industrial disputation, depressed prices for coal exports and an increase in interest charges associated with BHP and the Steel International Group's large and ambitious capital investment program.

When BHP's new plant is fully operational the Australian steel industry will have modern facilities which, in general, will be internationally competitive. With the additional advantage of access to relatively low cost and high quality locally available raw materials, the Australian steel industry has the potential to become the world's lowest cost steel producer and potentially a competitive exporter. However, the realisation of this potential lies almost entirely within the hands of the industry itself. It will require the effective and enlightened management of both capital and labour resources to place the industry's future development on a sound footing. A failure in the performance of either capital or labour-honourable senators should note this well-would not only represent a lost opportunity for the Australian steel industry but also, given the extremely competitive world steel environment, could jeopardise its existence.

While recognising the significance of capital investment to the long term viability of the domestic steel industry, it is the management of the industry's labour resources that is of greatest immediate concern to the Steel Industry Authority. A very clear, earlier warning bell was sounded when the annual report came out in September last year, five months ahead of the Minister's Press release. But there is more. The Authority says that the present level of industrial disputation within the steel industry is a clear indication that some of the parties at least have lost sight of their common goals. Moreover, it perhaps exposes a fundamental flaw in the lines of communication between management and unions and within unions. In a reference to Port Kembla, this is what the annual report had to say five months ago:

The fact that the level of disputation can largely be attributed to issues outside the direct control of the steel industry, namely changes to the New South Wales workers' compensation legislation, does not reduce the seriousness of recent events. In fact, it raises grave doubts as to the commitment by some of the parties to the security and development of the steel industry in general.

These were loud and clear alarms heard by some several months ago, but apparently not by the Government, as evidenced by the transparency of the Minister's wallpaper Press release. Unfortunately for the Government, the Press paid no attention to the release and read the report for themselves. But unfortunately for Australia, what was only last year being presented as a possible giant step forward for the steel industry has been allowed to deteriorate rapidly and thoroughly despite the severity of numerous warnings that the death of the industry can be foreseen within 12 years. After that short period there will not be any industry issue to strike over because there will not be any industry left. Let us also remember that it is not only the Steel Industry Authority which is sounding the alarm bells.

The shortcomings in union attitudes have also been highlighted in the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. It is a bipartisan and unanimous report which stated:

The Committee must conclude that the unions are no longer meeting their commitments. The unions have not adhered to the agreed dispute settling procedures and industrial disputation has reached pre-plan levels at Port Kembla.

The effectiveness of the Steel Industry Authority in this area has been negligible. Much progress must also still be made by unions regarding productivity, further increases being imperative if Australia is to attain long term international competitiveness.

Therefore it is clear that the Government's policy with regard to the steel industry is in a state of utter failure. As a result of that and as a result, particularly, of the militant attitude of trade unions which have no concern for this industry, the industry is in a state of grave doubt about its future and it has been said that it may not survive the end of this century. It is for that reason that I strongly support Senator Michael Baume's motion today.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill seeks to amend the Student Assistance Act 1973 which is the legislative basis for the provision of student assistance under Austudy and for the grant of post-graduate awards.
The proposed measures are designed to facilitate the prevention of fraud and the recovery of overpayments under student assistance schemes.

The Attorney-General recently announced the outcome of the Review of Systems for Dealing with Fraud on the Commonwealth. The main thrust of the Review's findings was that agencies affected by fraud should have the principal responsibility for its prevention and detection. It is intended to progressively implement measures to prevent, detect and recover moneys which have been wrongfully paid under programs administered by the Department of Employment, Education and Training.

As a first step towards making student assistance schemes less vulnerable and to assist in recovering overpayments, the Government is proposing that the Student Assistance Act be amended to bring it into line with the Social Security Act in matters relating to the gathering of information, and the recovery and write-off and waiver of overpayments in relation to the schemes. It is reasonable and proper that the powers provided to the various Commonwealth authorities for the administration of income support schemes should be similar, to the extent that this is feasible.

At present the Department of Employment, Education and Training obtains information from educational institutions and Government authorities to verify particulars provided by students in their applications. The proposed new section 31D will give legislative support for such arrangements and will facilitate the acquisition of information to ensure that the income tests are applied correctly and that the funds to support students, which are provided at considerable cost to the community, are directed to those for whom they are intended.

Recovery will be strengthened by the introduction of measures similar to those already provided in the Social Security Act, to recover overpayments from money owing to a debtor. The proposed new section 31a will allow overpayments of student assistance, social security or veterans benefits to be offset against an entitlement under the Student Assistance Act. The Bill will also amend the social security and veterans' legislation to extend their recovery provisions in a similar manner.

The Bill provides for the maximum penalties under the Student Assistance Act to be increased. At present the maximum penalty for offences under the student assistance legislation is $100. This has little deterrent value for people who might consider attempting to obtain money fraudulently. The maximum penalties as outlined in the new section 31h are to be increased to $2,000 and/or 12 months' imprisonment for individuals who make false or misleading statements or otherwise seek to deceive in order to obtain benefits unlawfully. There is a proposed maximum penalty of $10,000 for corporations which refuse to co-operate in arrangements to verify entitlements and to recover payments which should not have been made. The proposed penalties are in line with those prescribed under the Social Security Act.

The waiver and write off powers to be provided in the new section 31c are similar to those applying under the Social Security Act. At present, these powers in relation to student assistance schemes are exercised by the Minister for Finance under the Audit Act. It is considered more appropriate that they be exercised by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training as part of the overall responsibility for the administration of student assistance programs.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has foreshadowed an amendment to clause 22 which refers to section 97 of the principal Act. Amendment No. 4 which has been circulated by me is the amendment to which I refer and which, as I have said, I have already made mention of in my second reading stage speech. This section of the Family Law Act deals with the procedure in the Family Court of Australia. The key provision that we are referring to-subsection (3)-states:

SPEECH.PARA: In proceedings under this Act, the court shall proceed without undue formality and shall endeavour to ensure that the proceedings are not protracted.
Subsection (4), which the amendment is specifically directed to, states:
Neither the Judge hearing proceedings under this Act nor counsel shall robe.

Those provisions formed a very important part of the decision to establish the Family Court as what was known as a new kind of helping court. That is the phrase that was used to describe the new court which was being created under the Family Law Act. To those of us who were very much involved in those decisions and in formulating the legislation, to which I have already referred in my speech during the second reading debate, it seemed to be appropriate that such a court should not appear to be the same as other courts. I know that people in magistrates courts do not wear the ordinary regalia. Certainly counsel appearing in magistrates courts do not wear a gown or anything of that sort. I understand that in some States magistrates wear gowns, but certainly that is a new phenomenon to me. When I practised law in the magistrates courts, neither the magistrates nor counsel wore any sort of robe.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a good argument.

—The Minister will see why I have changed my mind in a minute. I understand that even magistrates now wear robes. The idea was that the Family Court should not appear to be the same as other superior courts in the land. As I said, the Family Court was established as a superior court. These provisions were put in the Act to differentiate that Court in an obvious way from other superior courts. In the other superior courts of the land-the Supreme Courts and Districts Courts of the States and the Federal Court of Australia-the traditional garb of wigs and gowns is worn at all times. But it was thought to be appropriate that this differentiation be made clear in this new type of helping court, with its emphasis on conciliation, reconciliation, mediation, and the provision of assistance by such experts as court counsellors, welfare workers and so on being a very prominent part of the workings of the Court.

SPEECH.PARA: The history of this Court over the past 12 years has caused many people, including me, to change their views. We have not changed our views about such essentials as judges having particular qualifications and an interest in and sympathy for the jurisdiction, all the resources available at present continuing to be available to the Court, emphasis being placed on conciliation, and so on. We have not changed our views about all those things, which have worked successfully and which I discussed at length in my speech during the second reading debate. I certainly agree with these words in subsection (3) of section 97 of the Family Law Act:
. . . the court shall proceed without undue formality and shall endeavour to ensure that the proceedings are not protracted.

That is a pretty good injunction to direct at any court. Perhaps all of our Acts that deal with courts should contain a similar provision. However, many people, including myself and members of the Opposition, now think that the prohibition on the wearing of wigs and gowns in the Family Court is not beneficial. In fact, it is thought to have been one of the problems with the Court, in that people do not see it as a superior court of the land because it appears to be so different from the other superior courts of the land. That has led to a lack of respect for the Court. Even though the Court is a special sort of court, it should be seen to be part of the mainstream of the superior judicial administration in Australia.

There is another argument that is used in favour of a return to judges in the Family Court being robed. I suppose it is part and parcel of the former argument, but it is more specifically directed to the need for judges to retain their anonymity. In that way there will not be the same focus on the person or the judge as an individual when he or she is pronouncing decisions that are unfavourable to certain parties. In other words, the parties see the judge as another person removing their child from their custody or taking away their property.

When I was Attorney-General a litigant telephoned me, following a decision being handed down in the Family Court, to complain that he had had seven farms taken away from him that week. So when property is reorganised it creates great bitterness. I did not like to say to him, `You must be pretty well off. You probably had at least 14, if not 21, farms'. That emphasises the strong bitterness that is felt by parties who are the subject of decisions in the Family Court. There is no doubt that such bitterness is felt by persons who are sentenced to long gaol terms in the criminal jurisdiction, and so on. In that jurisdiction judges are even more impersonalised; they wear even more formal robes in the criminal jurisdiction than in other jurisdictions. It provides a greater detachment of the person from the processes of the court. In other words, the judge is not seen to be a person but a remote judicial figure.

As it has turned out, only a small percentage of cases that come before the Family Court reach the stage of having a judicial decision handed down. The vast majority of them-more than 90 per cent-are settled. When the judges in the Family Court are brought into a matter and required to hand down a decision, the Family Court is acting like any other court. Therefore, the judges of that Court should be provided with the anonymity and the sense of authority that wearing robes gives them.

Robing is not confined to the legal profession. Many groups in the community wear uniforms of one sort of another. That is highly applauded by the community. There is a debate about when it is appropriate to wear wigs and who should appropriately do so. I know that there is a difference of opinion about that matter in this chamber. We on this side believe that the President should be robed, but honourable senators on the other side do not hold that view. It is natural enough that that sort of debate should take place. I think the desirability of judges of superior courts robing is pretty widely accepted. Indeed, that could be said of counsel who appear before such courts so that they are part of the formality or the solemnity of the process. Of course, academics often wear gowns, particularly on ceremonial occasions. An important part of maintaining discipline in the services is the wearing of uniforms.

For all those reasons, we think that, as part and parcel of the reconstruction of the Family Court and the restoration of its authority in the community as part of the superior court system, which it undoubtedly is, it would be helpful if it were seen to be the same as other courts and if judges were able to robe. The subsection of the Act that the Opposition seeks to delete simply prevents such judges from wearing robes. The acceptance of this amendment will not mean that we are directing them to robe. The judges will decide that, just as judges in other jurisdictions decide whether they will robe and whether counsel will robe. It will be left to the judges to decide, but I understand that a clear majority of Family Court judges wish to go back to robing and to require robing by counsel appearing before them. Therefore, it is likely that they would take up the option if we were to remove the provision preventing such a practice.

My personal view is that it is time that the superior courts in this land abandoned the wearing of wigs. I think that appropriate robing can be achieved without the wearing of wigs. There is a lot of debate in the legal profession as to whether the wearing of wigs should be retained or abandoned, but at this stage the wearing of wigs is part and parcel of the robing process. If the amendment is passed and if the Family Court judges decide to robe, they will wear wigs. That is appropriate so long as the rest of the superior court judges in Australia continue to wear wigs as part of their robe. The purpose of this amendment is that the Family Court should be seen to be exactly the same as other superior courts. Therefore, I move:
Page 8, clause 22, at the end of the clause, add: ``; and (c) by omitting subsection (4).''.
The amendment will permit the judges of the Family Court if they desire to do so, as I feel they will, to robe and be seen to be part of the mainstream of the judicial system, as they should be.

We are doing a number of things in this legislation, as is the Government, to try to achieve a greater acceptance of the Family Court and to emphasise its status as a superior court. The main object of the Bill is to give it additional jurisdiction, which will add to its authority and probably attract more people interested in serving on it. We have taken the view in this chamber that the salaries of Family Court judges should be commensurate with those of judges in the Federal Court and other superior courts in Australia, and have backed the establishment of further officials, such as the judicial registrar, a new minor judicial figure, who will take some of the workload off the judges to enable them to concentrate on their greater task. This is all part of the reconstruction to improve the quality of justice from the Family Court and the authority of its judges. The Opposition believes that a very important part of that process is that the judges should be able to robe and be seen as ordinary judges, part of the mainstream judicial system.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being almost 6.30 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter that I have to raise in the adjournment debate undoubtedly will seem to many honourable senators not a matter of great national moment, but it illustrates an interesting question in terms of the relationship between a particular statutory authority and this Parliament. I refer to the appalling behaviour of Australia Post in regard to the question of the recognition of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association (CPA) conference which is to take place in Australia later this year. The Commonwealth Parliamentary Association, as you, among others, Mr Acting Deputy President, would know, is a very important association. It brings together representatives of the Commonwealth parliaments, and it brings together a group of nations which have a common interest in the principle of parliamentary government and parliamentary democracy and who have a commitment to making parliament and democracy work. The Commonwealth Parliamentary Association conference will be the first function to take place in the new Parliament House. As such it is in itself a significant function.

SPEECH.PARA: Since 1961 the countries which have hosted the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association conferences have issued postage stamps in order to mark that undertaking. I have here a complete collection of the postage stamps which have been issued from those countries to mark the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association conferences. Going through them since 1961 they have been: Great Britain, Nigeria, Malaysia, Jamaica, New Zealand, Canada, Uganda, the Bahamas, Trinidad and Tobago, Australia, Malaysia, Malawi, the United Kingdom, Sri Lanka, India, Mauritius, Canada, Jamaica, New Zealand, Zambia, Fiji, the Bahamas, Kenya, the Isle of Man, Great Britain and Malaysia.

Australia Post will not issue a postage stamp to mark the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association conference. This has happened only once since 1961 when, in 1985, the CPA conference was held in Saskatchewan. The reason the Canadian authorities did not issue a postage stamp to commemorate that event was that the host was not the Parliament of Canada but the provincial Parliament of Saskatchewan. In 1988 the hosts of the CPA conference will not simply be the Parliament of Australia; they will in fact be the nine parliaments of Australia. They are all hosts and co-sponsors-the State parliaments, the Territory Parliament and the Parliament of Norfolk Island. Despite this, and despite requests from the Presiding Officers, from former President McClelland, from President Sibraa and from Speaker Child, Australia Post is declining to issue a postage stamp to meet the obligations which have otherwise been accepted.

In addition to this collection of postage stamps I have here the very large and quite impressive poster which marked the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association conference when it was held in Great Britain. Apart from the poster featuring the fact that a stamp is to be issued and will be an integral part of marking this on a worldwide basis, it also features a photograph of the new Parliament House in Canberra. This was displayed, I might say, at all post offices throughout Great Britain to mark the gathering in 1986. It says something about the Commonwealth, about the CPA, about Westminster Hall and about the traditions of parliamentary democracy, and it has a special feature about the postage stamp that was being put out to mark this particular occasion.

When we look at this collection of postage stamps we can see on them information about the Commonwealth, about the Parliamentary Association, about parliamentary buildings, about the symbols of the Parliament and about the underlying principles of the Parliament. They are all quite clearly indicated. But perhaps more interesting than anything else-and here I draw attention to the set which was issued for the twenty-seventh conference in Fiji-part of the stamp collection that was put out showed the flags of all of the members of the Commonwealth. It was an indication to people around the world that even in these times of trouble there is a family of nations which manages to maintain its collective identity and which manages to combine the interests of countries on all five continents.

Australia Post was approached two years ago by the authorities relating to the conference and asked to issue a postage stamp. Only recently has it informed people that it will not do that. It has made offers of pre-stamped envelopes and overprints of one sort or another in a totally unsatisfactory fashion. I put it to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that the Parliament, the elected Parliament, from time to time has the right to say that a body such as Australia Post, which exists only because we give it statutory authority, which is funded only because we allow it to be funded out of public revenues, also has a public responsibility to join with us in marking something which this Parliament thinks to be important. The holding of the CPA conference is important.

—I entirely endorse that remark made by Senator Michael Baume.
