I think it is an absolute disgrace.

SPEECH.PARA: I propose next week to give a formal notice of motion on this matter. But I do take this opportunity to draw this very unsatisfactory situation to your attention, Mr Acting Deputy President, to the attention of the Ministers and to the attention of the chamber as a whole. I take this opportunity to draw the attention of the executive and the board of management, or whoever it happens to be, at Australia Post to the fact that this Parliament does not regard that as the decent, satisfactory and proper exercise of its responsibilities. It should now take the necessary steps to make some arrangement for the issuing of a commemorative stamp properly to mark this important occasion which has been on foot by national parliaments since 1961. The current management of Australia Post thinks that it can arrogantly stand aside and say the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association, the organisation to which the Parliament of Australia and the nine sponsoring parliaments in Australia belong, is so irrelevant to it that it can simply cavalierly ignore a legitimate and proper request which I know has the endorsement of the Speaker and certainly of President Sibraa. I think Australia Post ought to be brought to account on this matter and we ought to demand that it take the necessary action forthwith.

I was not aware until now that Australia Post had taken this incredible decision not to issue a stamp to mark the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association (CPA) conference to be held in Canberra. SPEECH.PARA: Before I proceed with the matter about which I have listed myself to speak, I seek leave, on behalf of Senator Messner, to incorporate in Hansard a statement which he has prepared and which he has shown to the Minister at the table, the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds), and, I think, the Whip in the chamber. They have agreed that it could be incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
SENATOR EVANS TO EXPLAIN TELECOM POLITICAL INTERFERENCE CLAIM
Senator Evans has failed to adequately explain the recent claims of Government interference in Telecom.

Senator Tony Messner, Shadow Minister for Communications, said that there remains a strong suspicion that the Government has instructed Telecom to postpone sensitive restructuring proposals until after the New South Wales State elections.
In an internal note circulated within Telecom on 16 February, a manager in Victoria stated that the restructuring of Telecom had been postponed until after 19 March, the date of the NSW elections.
Senator Evans dismissed Mr Guthrie's note as completely false.

Yet a senior media spokesman for Telecom has been reported as confirming that the ``change process'' had been postponed for a few weeks. This was quoted by Paul Murphy on ``PM'' on Wednesday, 24th February 1988. It is very curious that the postponement will be only until after the NSW State elections.
The statement by the Telecom spokesman appears to directly contradict the comments by Senator Evans.

Furthermore, according to the Australian Telecommunications Employees' Association, there has been more than one memo circulated within Telecom advising that the ``change process'' had been postponed.
Senator Evans can no longer dismiss these allegations out of hand. They demand a full explanation as a matter of urgency.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise tonight the matter of adoptions in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). It is a matter in which I have had an interest for a considerable time, and I am the patron of the Adoptive Parents Association in the ACT. Most of the matters that I have pursued on behalf of members of that Association have in the past related to adoptions of babies from overseas, and there have been a number of problems with the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories in recent years. I shall not go over them tonight because they are recorded in the Hansard of Senate Estimates Committee F for 22 October 1987, when I put a number of questions to the Department. I asked whether the Department agreed that it took only 12 months in Victoria and New South Wales for one of these adoptions to be sorted out, whereas in the ACT assessment of the prospective parents took 20 to 22 months. I also asked how many staff were working in the area. I was told:

SPEECH.PARA: In full time equivalent it is four staff, I think.

I recognise the qualification. However, my next question asked how many couples were on the waiting list for approval. The answer was not given then but subsequently. The answer was that 135 couples were awaiting approval, consisting of 114 awaiting assessment and 21 undergoing assessment. There was no other comment on the number of staff, which I took to be four full time equivalent staff. It was indicated quite clearly that new procedures were being adopted and changes were being made. I have subsequently had a letter from the Department which sets out some of those arrangements in more detail.

I have a letter from a constituent that must be referred to the Minister. I shall not mention the constituent's name here-I do not think that is of any consequence-but I will convey it to the Minister. My constituent has been married for five years to a woman who, at the time of marriage, had a three-year-old daughter, and he wishes to adopt the child. He applied for adoption on 18 December 1986 and was somewhat surprised to be told that it would take about 16 months for the application to be assessed. This was not the adoption of an overseas child in which considerations would perhaps be looked at in a deeper fashion; this couple have married and the husband wishes to adopt his wife's child.

My constituent has been very patient. He contacted the Department on Monday last, as the 16 months are passing, and inquired as to when the assessment would take place. He was told that he would have to wait at least another 12 months. The child, who knows that adoption is to take place and who wants it to take place, who wants to feel that she is very much a part of this family, is now eight years old. She keeps asking what is happening. `Why not? Why don't you adopt me?', she asks my constituent. She is entitled to ask that. He has been told that the adoption section of the Department has three staff part time. I remind the Senate that the answer I got was that last October 135 couples were awaiting approval action.

My client is upset and distressed at what has occurred. He cannot believe that this is happening and he has raised it with me. I have had talks with the Department. I know that it is understaffed. There are about 14,000 employees in the Office of ACT Administration. The highest priority that the Minister must have when deploying these 14,000 staff must be to see that, where taxpayers are seeking something from the Department, there is an actual relationship between taxpayer, constituent and the Department, for the things that have to be done to make life work smoothly, and that there are sufficient staff to see that there are not undue delays and delays of this kind. I would myself have far fewer public servants in some of the massive policy sections in Government departments and more people on the counter, in the areas where people seek support or assistance. In this case we cannot say that my constituent is asking for much. He merely wants put into place the procedures which will enable him to adopt his wife's child, their having been married five years at this stage and having waited a reasonable time before they applied for the adoption.

The areas of housing, social security and the Commonwealth Employment Service are the places where we need public servants who can deal with the problems that people take to departments. If there are now only three part time staff in this section, I think the Minister's attention needs to be drawn to it. Even if there are four full time staff, there are not sufficient to deal adequately with the needs of families who wish to adopt a child. I urge the Minister to look closely at this matter to see that it is rectified and that the list moves more quickly and people are not put through what is occurring to my constituent. For people who have adopted one child and wish to adopt another, it is years between the first and second child. They are not in a position to plan their families as others might do and have the children spaced at the ages that they want. They are being forced to space them according to the machinations of the Department that are visited upon them. I say to the Minister that it is a matter that needs close attention.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment on the removal of the name of Mr Stephen Loosley from Australian Labor Party (ALP) advertising in New South Wales where, until today, he has appeared as the authorising agent for advertisements for the forthcoming State election on 19 March. This is a matter of some moment to this chamber because of Mr Loosley's associations both with members of the Labor Party in this chamber and with the administration of the Labor Party in general at both State and Federal level. The issue of concern relates to the scandalous diversion of electoral funding from a woodchip company, which was intended by that company to go to the publicly revealed election campaign fund of the Labor Party, into the secret maintenance fund so that the Labor Party would not be obliged in the last Federal election to confess that it was using woodchippers' money at a time when it was phonily protesting its pursuit of the greenie vote.

SPEECH.PARA: The decision taken by Mr Unsworth to replace Mr Loosley's name with his own was taken, according to a television report I saw tonight, because Mr Unsworth said, of the police report relating to this matter which has today, I understand, gone to the Director of Public Prosecutions. Senator Bishop asked a question on this very issue today in this place and it was treated with contempt by the Government, which pretended to be offended by the thrust of the question-a very proper question, in view of Mr Unsworth's remarks on the media this evening.

I wish to make what I believe to be some more disturbing points that emerged from Senator Bishop's earlier comments today on the question of the change to the New South Wales electoral Act that took place in June 1987. The remarkable coincidence of those changes in the electoral Act should be underlined. Senator Bishop quickly dealt with them, before proceeding to another matter, during the matters of public interest debate. I think it should be stressed that the information she revealed-that this change in the law took place which changed the reporting status of any gifts for administrative purposes in New South Wales-would have clearly been uppermost in the minds of Labor apparatchiks both at State and Federal level when dealing with any contribution to their funds, either electoral campaign funds or electoral maintenance funds. I believe that the onus is on officials of the Labor Party in those circumstances to explain publicly-no matter what the police inquiry finds-why they deliberately set out, it appears, to divert this money at a time when the subject of the manner in which these sorts of donations should be handled was a matter of major moment to that Party because of the change in the law.

Let us recall the dates. On 11 June, as I recall it, Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd sent a covering letter and a cheque for $10,000 to the Labor Federal President, Mr Mick Young. It was date stamped as having been received-as I recall seeing the letter reproduced in the newspapers-on about 14 June. At that point, even if those funds had been directed by the woodchip company to the administration and maintenance fund of the ALP, that letter and the $10,000 donation would have had to be revealed under the State law. Of course, two days later the State law changed. An administration cheque was no longer obliged to be revealed because the State law was changed to fit in with the Commonwealth law.

With that kind of timing situation, can any member of the Labor Party protest innocence regarding the handling of this matter-innocence of the knowledge that the law was being changed so that it would, in effect, have a retrospective impact? Although the cheque was received on 14 June the law that came into effect from 16 June would relate to the next return of the political party before the next election. It seems to me in the circumstances absolutely incredible that we have had this behaviour from Mr Loosley and Mr Young in recent times. They appear to be trying to create an impression that there was a simple and honest mistake. As I said, the change in the law must have been very high in their consciousness, yet in those circumstances there was an `honest mistake'.

I remind the Senate that within three days Mr Loosley's very strong recollection that Mr Young had indicated to him that the company wanted the money paid into the ALP's administration account changed to an acknowledgment-equally firmly held, apparently-that it was all Mr Loosley's fault, that he had found the letter which he had not acted on and that, apparently, Mr Young had given him no such instruction. Mr Loosley had also said that not 1c of Harris-Daishowa's donation was spent on Mr Jim Snow's campaign; in other words, the request of Harris-Daishowa was totally ignored. Yet on the very same day that it was receipted by the State Labor Party-and, of course, well after the change in law on 16 June; it was receipted on 24 June-and the acknowledgment went out to Harris-Daishowa, $6,000 was transferred to Mr Snow's campaign. But Mr Loosley has a very strong recollection that not 1c of Harris-Daishowa's donation was spent on Mr Snow's campaign.

However, according to the Sydney Morning Herald, Mr Snow is not prepared to confirm that he had been told by the company in advance that the money would assist his re-election campaign. I believe that Mr Snow has a particular responsibility to tell the chamber of which he is a member whether he was advised that he was to get assistance and that, when he received the $6,000, he assumed that that would have been part of a donation made by Harris-Daishowa to the Labor Party.

It seems to me that many answers are required by the Parliament, quite apart from the police inquiry, the report of which, I understand, has gone to the Director of Public Prosecutions today. There is one thing that I specifically want to know. It relates to the presence of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson-who, by the way, had no official role in the matter-in very close proximity to Mr Stephen Loosley, the Secretary of the New South Wales ALP, who, by the way, still appears to be in possession of his kneecaps.

TALK.START.PARA: —A bit like the Prime Minister at a sporting function.

—Indeed; he was as close to Mr Loosley as the Prime Minister is to the captain of a winning sporting team; I take the point, Senator. The close attendance of Senator Richardson is interesting. Mr Loosley is still equipped with kneecaps, although he has lost one thing-that is, his right to authorise New South Wales election advertising. This close association at the Press conference at which Mr Loosley sought to take the entire blame for the Labor Party's scandalous conversion of the woodchip money is significant. The Senate will recall that Mr Loosley declared Mr Young's innocence by claiming that he had belatedly found the missing Harris-Daishowa letter in his office and that this somehow absolved Mr Young from any guilt. I do not know what it absolved Mr Young from. Let us face it: did it absolve Mr Young from conspiring with Mr Loosley to use the money? It may well not. One does not know what Mr Loosley meant or, indeed, what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) meant, when they said that Mr Young was cleared by the discovery of the letter.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many things that could have happened as a result of that letter arriving and being sent from Mr Young's office to Mr Loosley's office. The discovery of that letter in Mr Loosley's office removes only one prospect-that is, that it may have been shredded. That is the only prospect that it removes. As to guilt, it removes no such suggestion and no such possibility. It is a matter for the police inquiry. The attempts by the Labor Party to influence the outcome of that inquiry by declaring Mr Young innocent are, I believe, ludicrous and reflect the normal standover tactics that one expects from this Party opposite.

Talking about standover tactics, why was Senator Richardson so closely present with Mr Loosley at the time of the mea culpa Press conference held by Mr Loosley? I ask that question in view of the very close personal relationship that exists between Mr Loosley and Senator Richardson, including their joint ownership of a home unit in Neutral Bay. I wonder whether the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) has taken any steps, as I believe he should have done to ensure that there was no possibility of any suggestion of impropriety surrounding this matter, to request the police inquiry to look into any role Senator Richardson may have had in this scandal. Unless Senator Richardson has some extraordinarily good reason for his close proximity to Mr Loosley, apart from the fact that they are business partners, which still would not explain why he would attend such a Press conference, I believe he should come forward and tell the Senate exactly why he was there. Whose interests was he protecting? How did this very busy Minister who looks after so many things and is so busy rushing around the rainforests of Queensland have time to attend this conference? I certainly believe this raises serious questions about the whole administration of the right wing Labor machine in New South Wales. I believe this Parliament, no matter what the outcome of the police inquiry, has the right to full and detailed explanations from the dramatis personae in this scandal, with the exception of Mr Young, who has taken his bear and gone home. I believe we have a right to know what has gone on. Although making a clean breast of it belatedly has become something of a required habit when Ministers in this Government have been found out, I suggest that in this case there is a requirement, no matter what the outcome of police inquiries, for the Ministers involved-certainly Senator Richardson-to come clean on what has happened. What was his attendance there all about? I think a failure to do so would at least convey to the people of Australia some indication of a concern that, while this Government and this Prime Minister continually talk about integrity, they have an inability to practise it.

I conclude simply by saying that I totally support what Senator Chris Puplick said tonight about Australia Post. I remind the Senate that this is the same Australia Post that wasted $120,000 of taxpayers' money by printing and overprinting a special America's Cup victory stamp before we had been defeated in the latest America's Cup challenge. If it is good enough for Australia Post to speculate with public money on a victory in the America's Cup which did not take place and to put a stamp with an appropriate `V' symbol overprint on it and if, in Australia Post's mind, that sort of thing is more important than a meeting of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association-an historic meeting; the first major meeting in the new Parliament House-all I can say is that the judgment of those people involved at Australia Post is such as to encourage many of us to the view that the sooner it is privatised the better.
